Such are these examples, roughly outlining the essentials to instruct future generations. Even if the *Responsive Manifestations in the Golden Registers of the Mystic Capital* were expounded for an entire kalpa, they could not be exhausted.

**Chapter Eighteen: Rewards of Merit**
The Lord of the Dao said: "Those who create images and copy scriptures in this life attain supreme victory and are reborn in the future as heavenly kings. Those who establish temples to deliver sentient beings in this life attain nobility and wealth and are reborn in the future as kings."

Those who perform the Dao and recite the scriptures in this life are protected by benevolent spirits and are reborn in the future with a wise and intelligent form. Those who observe fasts and perform prostrations in this life attain peace and happiness and are reborn in the future with a prosperous form. Those who uphold the precepts and burn incense in this life are revered and guarded by all the heavens and are reborn in the future with a complete and perfect human form. Those who offer scriptures and images in this life attain flourishing prosperity and are reborn in the future with a noble and wealthy form. Those who offer vegetarian meals and alms in this life enjoy abundant clothing and food and are reborn in the future with an upright and handsome form. Those who relieve the poor and destitute in this life are free from disasters and calamities and are reborn in the future with a powerful and victorious form. Those who refrain from consuming sentient beings in this life are free from illness and suffering and are reborn in the future with a long-lived form. Those who abstain from drunkenness and recklessness in this life are protected by divine spirits and are reborn in the future with a loyal and steadfast form. Those who abstain from pungent and meat-based foods in this life attain fragrance and are reborn in the future with a pure and clean form. Those who liberate and ransom lives in this life are free from unjust harm and are reborn in the future with a revered form. Those who make offerings to renunciates in this life are respected by others and are reborn in the future with a noble and esteemed form. Those who expound the Dharma and teach others in this life are honored by others and are reborn in the future as renunciates.

The rewards of merit and retribution are like an echo responding to sound, or a shadow following form—great or small, pure or turbid, they never deviate. Yet ordinary beings, deluded and ignorant, fail to recognize the causes and conditions of past lives. They do not believe in the consequences of sin and blessings, fortune and misfortune. They do not know that this present body arises from the field of blessings sown in a past life. They do not know that this body, once born, is already perishing; that this body is entirely transient and illusory; that this body is momentary and impermanent. Instead, they indulge in greed and stinginess, killing living beings, stealing, engaging in sexual misconduct and dissipation, consuming sentient beings, uttering harsh and deceitful words, slandering the scriptural teachings, and amassing wealth. They constantly assume they will live a thousand years in this life. With eyes open, they commit countless sins; with eyes closed, they enter the hells and cycle through rebirth. They spend their days creating sins, never repenting, unable to generate even a single thought of goodness to cultivate blessings for past, present, or future lives. They seek only to preserve their own bodies, planting the seeds of suffering, and worry only for their descendants, fearing they may not survive. Yet when the qi of life in this world is suddenly severed, they weep briefly, then fret over their sons and daughters, forgetting the kindness of their parents’ nurturing care. From beginningless time, they have imitated one another, never awakening—how profoundly foolish!

I pity you, who persist in such delusion, never awakening to yourselves. Thus, I reveal the causes and conditions of past lives, the consequences of sin and blessings, so that you may escape the river of suffering and desire. Yet sentient beings drift and drown in the sea of suffering. This world is called the *Realm of the Forsaken and the Wise*, also known as the *World of Mixed Retribution* or the *Heaven of Desire and Attachment*. Those born into it perish as soon as they arise, scatter as soon as they gather—like lightning, fleeting in an instant. It is impure, foul, and filthy, filled with birth, aging, illness, and death; pain, itching, and soreness; hunger, cold, heat, and dampness; water, fire, blades, and weapons; demonic spirits, ghosts, and thieves; poisonous winds and malevolent influences, all mutually harming one another. Death comes in every moment, never pausing for even an instant—how much suffering there is! Even the afflictions they see before their eyes, which entangle their own bodies, they fail to recognize. How then could they believe in the celestial realms, the blessed lands of immortals, the Dao of long life and deathlessness, or the freedom of non-action?

I observe that the lives of those born into this world are shorter than that of a mayfly; their dwellings are more cramped than a hair’s breadth; their foulness exceeds that of a latrine; their pleasures differ not from those of dung-beetles. Yet they remain unaware, perpetuating evil deeds—how could this not be suffering?

**Chapter Nineteen: The Generation of the Spirit**

The Great Compassionate and Universally Salvific Perfected One, in light of karmic retribution’s causes and conditions, inquired of the Most High. At that time, the Most High Lord of the Dao declared:

“I, by the Dao and qi, unfolded heaven and earth, cleaved apart yin and yang, and through the revolving transformations of causes and conditions, gave birth to the myriad things. I divided the spirit and distributed qi to nourish and sustain the people. From beginning to end, I have overseen the workings of life and death, thought after thought unceasing, feeding them with primordial harmony. Yet which among you mortals can comprehend this?

Now I shall dissect these causes and conditions for you, that those of the future may awaken to their primordial origins. When a person first receives a body, they emerge from the void and spontaneity. Turning yellow to white, they gather qi and congeal essence. The primordial father generates the spirit; the mysterious mother forms the shape. They accord with heaven and comply with earth, uniting and transforming yin and yang. From these two halves of causes and conditions, they receive their bones and flesh, all drawing upon past karma and encountering present conditions. They take heaven and earth as their likeness, harboring the sun and moon within. Through the transformations of yin and yang, the spirit and consciousness come and go.

Among the myriad transformations, humans are the most noble. Thus, when first entering the womb, the three qi subtly congeal, and the nine heavens obscurely revolve:
- In the first month, it is the *bao* (embryonic sac), and the qi of the *Yudan Wu-liang* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the second month, it is the *tai* (embryo), and the qi of the *Shangshang Chan Shan Wu-liang Shou* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the third month, the *hun* (ethereal soul) takes form, and the qi of the *Fan Jian Xu-yan* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the fourth month, the *po* (corporeal soul) is complete, and the qi of the *Jiran Dou-shu* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the fifth month, the viscera are generated, and the qi of the *Boluo Ni-mi Bu-jiao Le* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the sixth month, the bowels are transformed, and the qi of the *Dongxuan Hua-ying Sheng* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the seventh month, the orifices become clear, and the qi of the *Linghua Fan-fu* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the eighth month, the *jing* (essence) attaches, and the qi of the *Gaoxu Qingming* Heaven permeates the body;
- In the ninth month, the spirit descends, and the qi of the *Wu-xiang Wu-jie Wu-ai* Heaven permeates the body.

Eighteen thousand celestial spirits and eighteen thousand bodily spirits, inner and outer, unite to form thirty-six thousand spirits. All at once, the spirit is generated. Within the golden towers and jade pavilions, the purple gates and azure portals, the spirit is divided, distributed, and transformed, encircling the body within and without, corresponding inside and out. When voice and spirit are fully formed, the child is born in the tenth month.

While in the womb, the three primals nurture and the nine qi distribute transformations. Day and night, without cease, the spirit of former lives is transformed, receiving the substance of the present body. At first, within the womb, one fully knows the good and evil causes and conditions of past lives and perceives the origins of one’s birth. Yet upon consuming impure filth, one gradually forgets.

The head is round, symbolizing heaven; the feet are square, symbolizing earth. The left eye is the sun; the right eye, the moon. The hair is the stars; the eyebrows, the canopy of flowers. The nose is the gate of heaven; the mouth, the door of earth. The ears are the windows of heaven; the crown, Kunlun. The neck is the pillar of heaven; the five viscera, the five sacred peaks. The four limbs are the four seas. The skin, bones, joints, blood vessels, and mechanisms of the body emulate heaven and earth, containing yin and exhaling yang.

The generation and distribution of the spirit each have their overseers:
- The brain is the *Niwan*, where the Supreme Unity Sovereign Lord resides;
- The heart is the *Jiang Palace*, where the Controller of Destiny receives life;
- The liver is the *Qing Palace*, where *Wu-ying* governs the *hun*;
- The lungs are the *Su Palace*, where *Bai-yuan* tends the *po*;
- The kidneys are the *Xuan Palace*, where *Tao-kang* receives essence;
- The spleen is the *Huang Ting*, where the Yellow Emperor transforms the spirit.

The qi of *Shaoyang* transforms, and the essence of wood, the Year Star, is received and transformed within the body as the liver, where the three *hun* reside. They emerge above through the eyes, attended by nine guardians who oversee nine thousand spirits. The liver has seven lobes, governing the hair, skin, and the circulation of *ying* and *wei*.

The qi of *Taiyang* transforms, and the essence of fire, the Sparkling Deluder, is received and transformed within the body as the heart, where the fire spirit dwells. It emerges above as the tongue, attended by three guardians who oversee three thousand spirits. The heart has three lobes, seven orifices, and three hairs, resembling a lotus blossom. It governs the warmth of the spirit and qi, and the circulation of *ying* and *wei* for the hundred spirits.

The qi of *Shaoyin* transforms, and the essence of metal, the Grand White, is received and transformed within the body as the lungs, where the seven *po* reside. They emerge above through the nose, attended by seven guardians who oversee seven thousand spirits. The lungs have eight lobes, governing the teeth and protecting the sinews and bones.

The qi of *Taiyin* transforms, and the essence of water, the Chronographic Star, is received and transformed within the body as the kidneys. To the left is the Jade Lad; to the right, the Jade Maiden. The courtyard of essence transformation emerges above through the ears, attended by five guardians who oversee five thousand spirits. The kidneys have two, like half-moons, governing the essence and fluids, protecting the blood and marrow.

The primordial yellow qi transforms, and the essence of earth, the Quelling Star, is received and transformed within the body as the spleen, whence will and intent arise. It emerges above through the mouth, attended by twelve guardians who oversee twelve thousand spirits. The spleen is five inches long, governing the muscles and protecting the four limbs.

Circulating through the hundred parts of the body, the hundred spirits are generated, each with its own name. They enter and exit the various heavens, transforming unpredictably, coming and going without cease. Those who know this attain long life. In sitting and walking, recite and recall them, nurturing and protecting the body’s form, dispelling the myriad calamities, and subduing the hundred spirits.

The spirit of the hair emits mysterious light; the spirit of the crown connects to heaven. Before the crown is the spirit *Zhu-yang*; behind it, *Xuan-ming*. To the left of the crown is the spirit *Qing-guang*; to the right, *Bai-zhang*. The spirit of the forehead is *Tian-ting*; of the left eyebrow, *Cui-tong*; of the right eyebrow, *Yu-tong*. The spirit of the left eye is *Ri-guang*; of the right eye, *Yue-guang*. The spirit of the left cheek is *Yu-que*; of the right cheek, *Yu-liang*. The spirit of the left nostril is *Tong-yang*; of the right nostril, *Tong-yin*. To the left of the mouth is the spirit *Ming-tong*; to the right, *Tian-liang*. The spirit of the teeth is *Yu-guan*; of the left tooth, *Tian-zhong*; of the right tooth, *Tian-qing*. The spirit of the tongue is *Chi-tong*; of the upper lip, *Ting-gai*; of the lower lip, *Jing-yu*. The spirit of the left jaw is *Huang-fu*; of the right jaw, *Huang-mu*. To the left of the neck is the spirit *Tian-tong*; to the right, *Sheng-ping*. The spirit of the left shoulder is *Yuan-shan*; of the right shoulder, *Yuan-an*. The spirit of the left elbow is *Fei-long*; of the right elbow, *Fu-hu*. The spirit of the left hand is *Tian-ding*; of the right hand, *Tian-zou*. The spirit of the left fingers is *Jia-zu*; of the right fingers, *Yu-xiong*. The spirit of the left armpit is *Fu-gan*; of the right armpit, *Fu-dao*. The spirit of the left rib is *Wei-bian*; of the right rib, *Fang-fei*. To the left of the waist is the spirit *Dong-kai*; to the right, *Yao-ting*. The spirit of the left thigh is *Xuan-yu*; of the right thigh, *Xuan-shan*. The spirit of the left knee is *Zhuan-sheng*; of the right knee, *Qu-ting*. The spirit of the left shin is *Tian-zhu*; of the right shin, *Tian-guan*. The spirit of the left foot is *Lun-kong*; of the right foot, *Yun-xu*. The spirit of the left ankle is *You-hu*; of the right ankle, *Fu-lang*. The spirit of the chest is *Tian-tian*; of the abdomen, *Bao-ling*. The spirit of the private parts is *Ji-guan*; of the coccyx, *You-guan*. The spirit of the back is *Zi-fang*; of the spine, *Tong-ping*. The spirit of the navel is *Zhong-ping*; of the skin, *Bao-luo*; of the flesh, *Wei-fei*; of the bones, *Nei-ding*.”

Each spirit spans seven inches, appearing in the form of an infant. Within the human body, they absorb qi to become spirits, ensuring the flow of *rong* and *wei* and the natural transformation of qi. In harmony with the virtue of Heaven and Earth, they enter and exit the body, promoting good and halting evil, ceaselessly day and night.

When a person is unborn, they do not exist; once born, they embody the image of Heaven and Earth, inhaling yin and exhaling yang, their fate suspended by Heaven. Heaven grants them a lifespan of forty-three thousand two hundred days—one hundred and twenty years—with each day recorded by the Lord of Destiny and inscribed in the registers of the various heavens.

I have often commanded the Emperors of the Heavens to summon the Five Emperors, the Three Realms, the Four Offices, the Southern and Northern Dippers, the Ten Heavenly Generals, the Nine Earth Envoys, the Seven Divine Lads, the Eight Divisions of Heavenly Spirits, and all divine beings to roam the mortal world, inspecting and assessing sins and blessings, the fortunes and misfortunes of men and women.

I have also dispatched the Most Sacred and Exalted Perfected Ones of Wondrous Conduct, the Heavenly Immortals, Flying Immortals, Divine Immortals, Earthbound Immortals, the Five Sacred Peaks, the Four Waterways, the Sun, Moon, and Stars, the Three Officials, the Nine Bureaus, and the twenty-four thousand spirit offices. They bear standards and banners, soar through the void, wield talismans and registers, and patrol ceaselessly. Every three days, they report once; every seven days, they memorialize; every hundred days, they conclude—without pause for even a moment.

For those who cultivate goodness and power, the Heavenly Lads and the Offices of Life and Record immediately extend their years, dispel disasters, and scatter misfortunes, ensuring abundant clothing and food. For those who commit sins and accumulate evil, the Heavenly Emperors dispatch the Demon Kings of the Six Heavens to seize their souls and present them before the Three Officials. If their allotted lifespan is not yet complete, it is due to the sins they have committed. Those who fulfill their destined span do so through the accumulation of goodness.

Thus, when a person nears the end of life, it is because the Earthly Offices have memorialized the Heavens, and the Heavens, upon inspection, determine their death according to the celestial registers. They then command the officials of the Three Realms and the Four Offices, along with the Five Emperors, to collect the soul and sever the breath of life.

Whenever a person suffers illness, punishment, calamity, official disasters, imprisonment, water or fire, blades or weapons, or any manner of suffering, it is the result of the underworld’s examination and punishment. At such times, one should broadly establish fields of blessing: perform purification rites, uphold precepts, recite scriptures, practice the Dao, burn incense, scatter flowers, lecture on and recite repentances, make offerings, cultivate resolve, release and redeem lives, aid the poor, rescue those in peril, copy scriptures, create images, receive precepts, repent, and pay homage to the ten directions.

First, create the Savior from Suffering Heavenly Worthy, the Banner of Deliverance from Calamity, the Banner of Life Protection, the Banner of Lifespan Extension, the Banner of Life Continuation, and the Banner of Disaster Dispelling. Copy this scripture, recite it day and night, and for three, seven, or even a hundred days, offer repentance to the Heavens. Donate family wealth—treasures, goods, fields, dwellings, servants, silks, fine brocades, carriages, horses, rare curios, fine garments, utensils, bedding, and curtains—kneeling before the Heavens to repent for transgressions. The Three Officials will then release the soul, extend life, and increase the allotted span, allowing rebirth.

If Heaven’s mandate is nearing its end and the celestial tally is nearly exhausted, it cannot be saved. Yet if one, in the realm of the Great Yin, at the hour of death, makes vows, repents, donates clothing, bedding, and all possessions, receives precepts, and repents, the merit gained is inconceivable. From the moment of death until the seventh day, create scriptures and images, hold purification feasts, practice the Dao, recite repentances, burn incense, light lamps, release and redeem lives, aid the poor, and continue these acts day and night to deliver the deceased, enabling them to ascend to Heaven.

Why is this so? From the moment of death until the seventh day, the Heavenly Lads, the Four Offices, the Five Emperors, and the officials of the Three Realms all come to oversee, inspecting sins and blessings, and reporting to the Heavenly Offices. I dispatch the Seven Divine Lads to re-examine their conduct, determine good and evil, and assign them to the Gate of Life. If good, they ascend to Heaven, their blessings flowing to descendants, ensuring present peace, freedom from fear, a pure household, and success in all endeavors. If evil, they suffer calamity, their sins flowing to descendants, causing death, illness, misfortune, official disasters, slander, manifold terrors, and confusion in life—all undertakings will fail.

Thus, the seven days following death are the most critical for deliverance. After this period, every seventh day, the Divine Lads record the soul of the deceased and return to the household to review sins and blessings. After forty-nine days, the Five Heavenly Generals descend to seize the soul, and the Nine Earth Envoys come to take the *po*. The Generals wish to send them to Heaven, while the Envoys wish to send them to Earth. Every five days, they weigh sins and blessings; those with more blessings ascend to Heaven, while those with more sins descend to Hell. The two spirits of good and evil descend every ten days to examine and determine sins and blessings.

Therefore, from the moment of death, the first seven days, the second seven days, up to the forty-ninth day and the hundredth day, the deceased’s family must perform deliverance rites to ensure rebirth in a good place and attain peace. This is the foremost act of merit. On the first seventh day, create one image of the Savior from Suffering Heavenly Worthy, copy one section of this scripture, make one spirit banner, and light seven lamps. By the second seventh day, create two images of the Heavenly Worthy, copy two sections of the scripture, make two banners, and light fourteen lamps. By the seventh day, create seven images, copy seven sections of the scripture, make seven banners, and light forty-nine lamps. Increase these accordingly until the hundredth day, when one hundred images, one hundred sections of the scripture (recited one hundred times), one hundred banners, and seven hundred lamps are made. Though the number of scriptures, images, banners, and lamps may reach hundreds of thousands or millions, they must adhere to the number seven. For the poor, adjust according to their means, but aim for seven hundred days.

The Dao Lord said: The Seven Divine Lads are the essence of the Northern Dipper in Heaven.

When a person first resides in the womb, at the seventh month, the Seven Divine Lads descend into the body, opening and illuminating the seven apertures. Their names are recorded in the Northern Dipper: the first is Heavenly Canopy, the second Heavenly Interior, the third Heavenly Charge, the fourth Heavenly Assistance, the fifth Heavenly Quail, the sixth Heavenly Heart, and the seventh Heavenly Pillar. Each rides a sevenfold-brilliant cloud chariot, clad in five-colored garments, accompanied by divine lads from the ten directions, with legions of immortals, soldiers, and horses numbering seventy million each. They constantly dwell among humans, manifesting in various forms—tall or short, male or female—to teach and transform. Holding talismans and records, they precisely assess merits and transgressions, good and evil karmic conditions, without the slightest error. Those who know this shall attain immortality and eternal life.

The Dao Lord said: There are also Eight Divine Lads.
The first is the Golden Flower Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Origin. He governs the Son of Heaven, crown princes, consorts, and ancestral temples; the renewal of the old and establishment of the new; the enthronement of rulers and replacement of sovereigns; the offering of counsel and rejection of folly; tribute and taxation; wealth and treasures; chariots, horses, and attire; palaces, gardens, and hunting parks; ponds, terraces, and pavilions; ranks, emoluments, and summons; and all movements and travels.
The second is the Yellow Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Maiden. He governs dwellings, tombs, and mausoleums; livestock and crops; granaries and storehouses; sons and daughters; longevity and premature death; illness and disease; and the construction of earthworks, mountains, rivers, and valleys.
The third is the Pure Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Might. He governs roads, vehicles, and vessels; forests, trees, flowers, and fruits; and thunder, lightning, wind, and rain.
The fourth is the Bright Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Life. He governs wells, stoves, doors, and gates; ditches, latrines, and cesspits; impurity, filth, and lewdness; and falsehood and deceit.
The fifth is the Cinnabar Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Radiance. He governs prisons and confinement; documents and childbirth; bloodshed, fire, and disasters.
The sixth is the Mysterious Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Communication. He governs life spans and their extension or curtailment; demons, specters, and goblins; curses, prayers, and sacrifices; and all spirits and ghosts.
The seventh is the Purple Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Perfection. He governs wandering souls and lost spirits; roaming corpses and the dead; and those sunk in hell.
The eighth is the White Spirit Lad, whose divine name is Heavenly Prosperity. He governs fathers, mothers, sons, and daughters; husbands, wives, and childbirth.

These Eight Divine Lads sometimes ride wind, rain, clouds, and thunder, mounting dragons and tigers as they move in and out of the human realm, observing good and evil. If one is good, fortune follows; if evil, misfortune ensues. They respond according to karmic conditions, never erring. You, men and women, should but recite this sutra, and the Eight Divine Lads will come to protect you, bestowing blessings, dispelling calamities, eradicating sins and transgressions—effects beyond imagination.

The Dao Lord said: No one receives life without coming from past karma. Thus, each is endowed with a divine and exceptional nature, each with its own karmic conditions. Whether sinful or auspicious spirits, fortune or misfortune, all arise from one’s karma. Therefore, differences in longevity or premature death, nobility or lowliness, prosperity or adversity, beauty or ugliness, wealth or poverty, foolishness or wisdom—all vary. Even birds, beasts, insects, fish, chickens, dogs, grasses, and trees are likewise. You, men and women, should each reflect upon this.

The Dao Lord said: The receiving of a human body is a rare encounter. Once it decays, when will one meet such an opportunity again for ten thousand kalpas? **Verified Attainment, Chapter Twenty-One**

The Dao Lord addressed Universal Salvation, saying: "If good men and good women can arouse the one mind, copy scriptures and cast images, establish temples to deliver beings, practice charity, observe fasts, uphold precepts, advance with vigor, endure humiliation, and maintain purity—whether great or small, provisional or real, profound or shallow, beginning or end—all must be genuine, with witnesses to attest. One must not outwardly feign reputation while inwardly lacking true substance. Those who seek empty fame without sincerity, even if they practice the Dao, recite scriptures, burn incense, bow in worship, dwell in mountains, enter seclusion, abstain from grains, relieve distress, aid the poor, cultivate truth, and study the Dao, if their devotion is not wholehearted, they will fail to achieve spiritual resonance.

There was once a man named Liu Huangmin, whose family was exceedingly wealthy. He commissioned scriptures and images, burned incense, and bowed in worship, inviting Daoist practitioners to observe fasts and recite scriptures. Yet his heart was not fully devoted; he sought only fame."

Within a hundred years, the body dies and transforms into a phoenix. After sixty years, it reverts to human form, the family grows exceedingly wealthy, and great merit is established. After thirty years, one achieves liberation through the corpse and enters the Azure Flower Palace. There was a man named Huang Anshi who entered the mountains to study the Dao. Within a stone chamber, he recited scriptures and bowed in worship, yet his heart was not wholly devoted, and he sought only to soar aloft. After forty years, he transformed into a soaring swan-goose. After ninety years, he was reborn as a woman, her form and countenance refined. Delighting in divine immortals, her sincerity moved heaven. After fifty years, the Radiant Jade Maiden descended and bestowed upon her the Five Sprouts Method of the Numinous Treasure. Practicing it for thirteen years, she ascended in broad daylight and entered the Yellow Canopy Heaven, becoming a Heavenly Maiden, where she has lived for seven thousand years.

There was a man named Wang Ziqui who abstained from grains and lived alone in the empty mountains, yet cultivated no other practices. After sixty years, he transformed into blue stone. Thirty years later, thunder split the stone asunder, and from within emerged a dragon that entered the Golden Hall Mountain, dwelling among the scripture halls of Daoist practitioners. After eight years, hearing Daoists recite scriptures and observe precepts, he transformed and was reborn at the gate of the Pure Brahmā King, where he established great merit. After twenty-four years, the Eastern Flower Perfected One secretly transmitted the divine elixir. Consuming it, he lived for three hundred years. With a heart ever earnest, he encountered an assembly of Daoists who bestowed upon him this scripture. Cultivating it for sixteen years, he ascended in broad daylight and became the Great Ultimate Immortal King.

There was a man named Han Yuanshou who secluded himself in meditation, reciting scriptures without single-minded devotion. One day, heavenly fire burned his dwelling, and the scriptures flew up to heaven. Over ninety years, Yuanshou transformed into a spirit of wood.

There was a man named Li Zhengxuan, originally a hunter who roamed the mountains in pursuit of game. Arriving at a mountain, he encountered a Daoist studying the Dao and devoted himself wholeheartedly to serving him. For thirty years, he toiled without retreat. The Daoist asked, "Do you wish to attain longevity?" Zhengxuan bowed deeply and replied, "Even birds and mice cling to life. I wish to be granted extended years. I shall serve you all my life without complaint or negligence." The Daoist said, "Simply pay homage to that withered tree at the foot of this mountain, and you shall naturally gain something." Zhengxuan then worshipped it day and night. After thirteen years, the withered tree blossomed with extraordinary radiance. Knowing his sincerity, the Daoist bestowed upon him this scripture. After thirty years, he soared through the empty void.

There was a man named Zhong Qi Ling who entered the mountains to study the Dao. For a hundred years, his sincerity and resolve were unwavering. Heavenly demons descended to test him, transforming into a starving tiger that entered his chamber. Qi Ling stretched out his leg to it. The demon, perceiving his heart, reverted to its true form. The Celestial Clerk of Immortals and the Five Thearch Perfected Ones descended to bestow upon him this scripture. After seventeen years, he gained mastery over transformations and entered Mount Penglai.

There was a man named An Duming who recited scriptures in the mountains for thirty-seven years. The Central Yellow Perfected One transformed into a hunter and offered him a venomous serpent. Duming joyfully accepted it, and the serpent turned into golden lingzhi. The Central Yellow, moved by his steadfast heart, bade him consume the lingzhi. His body emitted golden light. For five hundred years, he wandered the Five Marchmounts and became the Left Immortal Duke of the Great Ultimate.

There was a man named Zhou Huihua who delighted in almsgiving, aiding the poor, and enduring hardship without weariness. The Wisdom Contemplation Perfected One disguised himself as an ordinary man and sought alms from him. Huihua, moved with compassion, gave tenfold more than usual. The Perfected One then feigned illness, lying bedridden for three hundred days, emitting foul odors. Huihua showed no sign of disgust. One night, the Perfected One said to him, "I knew your utmost sincerity and came to test you." Huihua bowed and replied, "This foolish one lacks understanding. I have been mistakenly praised. I wish to attain extended years." Thereupon, he was granted the divine elixir. Consuming it, he lived for eight thousand years. Cultivating this scripture, he now serves as the Western Flower Immortal.

There was a man named Zhang Yanguang who served Daoist practitioners for seventy-three years, unwavering from beginning to end, his heart never faltering. The Responding World Perfected One disguised himself as a Daoist, his appearance emaciated, his clothing foul and filthy, and sought lodging. Soon after, he fell ill and died within seven days, his body swiftly decaying. Yanguang mourned him more deeply than for his own kin. The Responding World Perfected One, recognizing his utmost sincerity, revived and bestowed upon him this scripture. After two hundred years, he became ageless and entered Mount Fulai.

There was a man named Qiu Baoxiang who cultivated the Dao in Mount Tongbai for three hundred and sixty years, having already attained extended life. One day, the Wheel Heaven Lad disguised himself as a hunter and sought shelter with him. In the night, he set fire to Baoxiang’s dwelling. Baoxiang showed no change of expression. The lad then transmitted to him the Dao of liberation through transformation, and one day, he flew into the Purple Empyrean.

There was a man named Zhao Changming, a Daoist of Mount Taihe who entered Mount Haiyu to study the Dao for over seven hundred years. One day, mountain spirits, great deities, and various demons came to test Changming. Some appeared as immortals, others as Confucian scholars, now soaring, now crouching, transforming in myriad ways. Changming said to them, "You are mere mountain sprites and petty ghosts. How dare you disturb me?" Thereupon, he pointed at them with the scripture, and each reverted to their true forms, cupping their hands in reverence. The Daoist then expounded the Dharma and administered the precepts. Three hundred years later, the mountain spirits transformed into benevolent deities and presented Changming with these blossoms and fruits, recounting their past karmic ties and seeking to receive the precepts anew. Changming then performed repentance rites and administered the precepts. After a hundred years, he was reborn in the Pure Brahmā Realm as the daughter of a wealthy family, her form and countenance refined, her wisdom and intelligence keen. Delighting in scriptures and the Dharma, she established great merit and became a female Daoist. After forty-seven years of diligently reciting scriptures and precepts, the Golden Flower Jade Maiden bestowed upon her this scripture. One day, she entered the Earth Lung Mountain and gained thirty thousand years of life, now serving as the Perfected Consort of the Great Ultimate.

When Perfected Ones descend to test disciples, they may disguise themselves as the poor and lowly, the hungry and cold, the gravely ill, the maimed, or those begging for children. They may appear as worthies, heavenly demons, or transform into spirits and goblins—changing in countless ways to refine and test cultivators.

Only when their sincerity is fully realized does the initiation of deliverance begin. All future men and women should take heed of this.

**Chapter Twenty-Two: The Gate of Gathering Causes**

Puji asked: "Sentient beings are boundless, their perceptions and views diverse. They create good and evil causes, their roots and foundations differing. If we were to universally open the Ten Divisions, our wisdom and strength would not suffice. Yet if we preach the One Vehicle, awakening and understanding would be difficult to attain. How, then, should we determine the proper approach?"

The Dao Lord replied: "By responding to their capacities to awaken, no method fails to gather them in. Knowing the essentials, one may yet open the way. For those suited to the middle, what approach would not be fitting?"

Puji said: "The principle of essentials is precisely what I wish to hear."

The Dao Lord replied: "If sentient beings delight in killing, harming, and injuring, then gather them through the Gate of Compassion. If they steal or plunder, gather them through the Gate of Righteous Sharing. If they indulge in licentiousness, gather them through the Gate of Chastity. If they are miserly and greedy, gather them through the Gate of Generosity. If they are wrathful and contentious, gather them through the Gate of Joy. If they are foolish and deluded, gather them through the Gate of Expedient Means. If they engage in frivolous speech, gather them through the Gate of Simplicity and Rectitude. If they lie and deceive, gather them through the Gate of Trust and Compliance. If they curse and revile, gather them through the Gate of Recitation and Invocation. If they slander and malign, gather them through the Gate of Exposition and Teaching. If they are arrogant and contemptuous, gather them through the Gate of Reverence and Worship. If they are stubborn and overbearing, gather them through the Gate of Gentleness and Humility. If they disbelieve in karma, past lives, and destiny, gather them through the Gate of Causes and Conditions. If they cling to existence or nonexistence, gather them through the Gate of the Middle Way. If they discriminate between self and other, gather them through the Gate of Equality. If they are greedy, filthy, and defiled, gather them through the Gate of Purity. If they are rigid and unyielding, gather them through the Gate of Cyclic Transformation. If they ceaselessly create and act, gather them through the Gate of Non-Action. If they are narrow and unchanging, gather them through the Gate of All-Pervading Penetration. If they are restless and competitive, gather them through the Gate of Stillness and Concentration. If they are sorrowful and joyless, gather them through the Gate of Carefree Ease. If they are bound by afflictions, gather them through the Gate of Liberation. Through these twenty-four gates, all are constantly gathered in, and sentient beings attain peace and happiness—is this not essential?"

Puji said: "Though this is essential, it still seems too numerous. Formerly, the Heavenly Worthy taught the principle of no-characteristics, gathering and transforming sentient beings through the truth of non-form. Could it not be simplified further?"

The Dao Lord replied: "That was the form of no-form, uniting all in the One Vehicle. Here, the forms of form are shown, seeking to harmonize the myriad dharmas."

Puji said: "If that was no-form, from what did the no-form unite the One Vehicle? Now that form is shown, how can form harmonize the myriad dharmas?"

The Dao Lord replied: "The no-form of form is absent, and thus its form unites the One Vehicle. The form of form is extinguished, and thus its form seeks to harmonize the myriad dharmas."

Puji said: "If form exists, then it is bound to form—how can it harmonize? If form is absent, then it is formless—from what does it unite?"

The Dao Lord replied: "Originally, form was taken as no-form, and thus through its absence it could unite. Form extinguishes form, and through extinction it can harmonize."

Puji said: "Could one not simply gather through non-gathering, without further expounding the gathering of causes?"

The Dao Lord replied: "I originally gathered and transformed sentient beings through non-gathering. Yet sentient beings have not awakened, so I speak of gathering. If sentient beings awaken, there is also no gathering of causes."

**Chapter Twenty-Three: The Chapter on Generation and Transformation**

The Dao Lord said: "When heaven and earth were yet undivided, all was chaotic and indistinct, a formless expanse. The wondrous transformation of the Primordial Beginning turned and unfolded: the pure qi ascended and congealed to form heaven; the turbid qi descended and solidified to form earth. The essence of yang became the sun; the essence of yin became the moon. The essences of the sun and moon became the stars. Harmonious qi became humans; peripheral qi became beasts; dense qi became birds; attached qi became insects; and spirits established images. Species mutually arose, converging to generate and nurture. Each had its causes and conditions, following its karmic retribution, drifting or sinking as fate decreed. Some were foolish, some wise; some benighted, some enlightened; some great, some small; some turbid, some pure; some long-lived, some short-lived; some base, some noble—thousands of distinctions, myriad forms, all received their shapes from the Dao. They devoured one another, the strong preying upon the weak, deceit and cunning arising between them, with sin and blessing crisscrossing. Those who cultivated goodness obtained blessing; those who created evil incurred punishment.

The Primordial Beginning, mindful of the world, taught and transformed humanity, from kalpa to kalpa, their number like the sands of the Ganges. The unfolding of heaven and earth, the generation of yin and yang—none of this was not brought about by the Primordial Beginning. When the Primordial Beginning appeared in the world during the Dragon Han era to teach and transform, he was called the Formless, sheltering all beings and saving sentient beings. In the Yan Kang era, he governed the turning of the kalpa and was called the Nameless, spreading transformation through the lands and delivering gods and humans. When the Red Radiance dawned, he was again called the Brahmanic Form, descending to save beings, his compassionate aid boundless. In the Kai Huang era, he was called the Void Sovereign, shaping and molding the cosmos and giving rise to the consciousness of beings. When the Supreme Sovereign arose, he was called the Primordial Beginning in totality, gathering and transforming all heavens.

The Primordial Beginning’s turning of the wheel is cyclical, beginning and ending without cease, like the four seasons, returning endlessly. Adapting to beings, he assumes myriad forms and countless names—sometimes ordinary, sometimes sacred; sometimes wise, sometimes foolish. Riding clouds and commanding qi, clad in yellow robes and black caps, dragon robes and tiger belts, with jade countenances and golden visages—sometimes great, sometimes small, entering and exiting without obstruction, generating and transforming all things, sheltering and protecting sentient beings. The ignorant, lost in darkness—who can fathom him? Now, I have received the mandate to govern the Dharma Wheel, to uphold and practice the teachings of the scriptures, and dare not transgress."

You, men and women, should each devote yourselves wholeheartedly.

Pujì asked: "The Heavenly Worthy has often spoken of kalpas—how many years does one kalpa comprise?"

"How many kalpas have passed since the Heavenly Worthy attained the Dao?"

The Dao Lord replied: "A kalpa is the name for the transformation of heaven and earth. There are two kinds: the great kalpa and the small kalpa.

The great kalpa refers to the uppermost three realms and eighteen heavens, and the lowermost nine layers and thirty-six earths—where the disasters of water, fire, and wind burn, scour, and sweep away all beings within, leaving none remaining. In darkness profound, without light or form, the Three Caverns’ great Dharma, those who study the Dao and realize truth, are welcomed below by dragon chariots and all ascend to the Brahman conduct. All miscellaneous lesser teachings that do not enter the Great Vehicle perish with the kalpa, reduced to ashes.

The small kalpa refers to the impermanence of all formed beings, moment by moment, where worlds change and forms shift—this is called a kalpa. Yet the karmic fruits of sentient beings, their encounters with conditions, vary in duration: some brief, some long, some prolonged, some hastened. If one cultivates wholesome thoughts and the Dao, upholds precepts and holds to the scriptures, then days and months are extended, and one’s allotted lifespan is fulfilled. If one commits manifold transgressions and disbelieves in causes and conditions, then days and months are cut short, and a hundred years remain unfulfilled. The number of years—whether many or few—cannot be known by calculation; only by analogy can one grasp their measure.

Consider a great stone, perfectly square on all four sides, each face four hundred *li* wide, and equally high. A flying deity brushes it once every nine years with an object as light as a fly’s wing—when the stone is worn away, that is one kalpa.

Or consider a city, perfectly square on all four sides, each face four hundred *li* wide, and equally high, filled to the brim with mustard seeds. A flying deity removes one seed every nine years—when the mustard seeds are exhausted, that is one kalpa.

Or consider a square enclosure, each side four hundred *li* wide, filled with fine dust. A flying being removes one speck of dust every seven years—when the dust is gone, that is one kalpa.

Pujì, reflect on these three analogies, and you may grasp their measure. As for the number of kalpas since I attained the Dao—even if counted by these three, it cannot be known."

Pujì said: "Now that I have heard the Heavenly Worthy’s wondrous discourse, all doubts are dispelled—it is inconceivable, inconceivable."

*Thus concludes Scroll Nine of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure Scripture on Karmic Retribution and Causes and Conditions.*

*Scroll Ten of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure Scripture on Karmic Retribution and Causes and Conditions begins: The Broad Governance, Chapter Twenty-Four.*

The Great Compassionate and Great Merciful Perfected One of Universal Salvation, on account of karmic retribution and causes and conditions, inquired of the Most High. At that time, the Most High Lord of the Dao said:

In the worlds of the ten directions, each has five billion, five myriad, five thousand, five hundred fifty-five billion, five myriad, five thousand, five hundred fifty heavens, arranged in ordered domains and established as celestial palaces. Above the heavens and below the earth, below the earth and above the heavens, sun, moon, and stars, mountains, rivers, peaks, and streams—condensing qi and soaring clouds—form palaces of gold and jade, halls of treasure and chambers of jasper, halls of rosy clouds and purple abodes, star gardens and cloud forests, phoenix courtyards and simurgh gardens. Suspended in the void, spanning the space beside sun and moon, dividing realms and arranging precincts, they bear ten thousand kinds and a thousand names, filling all without gap.

Perfected Immortals and Supreme Sages, Celestial Emperors and Celestial Masters dwell in each place, each expounding scriptures and teachings. They oversee registers and records, the causes and conditions of life and death, the fate of men and women, good and evil, fortune and misfortune, examining and assessing day and night, distinguishing between humans and heavens. Within each direction, within each heaven, there is the Great Dao, there is the Heavenly Worthy, there is the Celestial Emperor, there is the Celestial Master, there are Perfected Immortals and hosts of sages, the Four Controllers and Five Emperors, envoys and generals, spirits of good and evil, the Five Dipper numina—each teaching and establishing different laws. All are governed and transformed by me.

Karmic retribution of good and evil, the life roots of men and women, the pairing of sin and blessing, the causes and conditions of past lives, even the grasses, insects, and all sentient beings—none do not await my dispensation of qi to receive life.

**Chapter Twenty-Five: The Assembly of Perfected Ones**

The Lord of the Dao addressed Universal Salvation, saying: All that has form is entirely fleeting and illusory, perishing in every thought, never pausing for even a moment—suffering and affliction in the cycle of rebirth. Ordinary beings, unaware, shuttle through the Three Paths, enduring myriad kalpas of bitterness, receiving bodily forms and suffering the fetters of affliction. All arises from deluded thoughts and inverted views, fixating the mind.

You men and women must extinguish all deluded thoughts. When deluded thoughts are extinguished, you will then meet the true and real. You must stabilize your resolve, contemplate all dharmas with stillness, and see that none are not empty. Both within and without, self and mind are wholly dissolved, freed from all fetters. You will ascend the gate of liberation, enter and exit with ease, abide in non-action and spontaneity, neither born nor destroyed, forever severing the causes of suffering.

Universal Salvation said: Sentient beings suffer affliction, ever bound to bodily form, trapped in the cycle of birth and death, unable to free themselves. By what expedient means may deluded thoughts be removed?

The Lord of the Dao said: The deluded thoughts and inverted views of sentient beings all arise from the mind. They forcibly generate distinctions, fixating on the self, deluded by contact with phenomena, every thought a delusion. Due to this error, they are inverted and submerged, drifting in the cycle of birth and death, unable to free themselves. You must stabilize your resolve and contemplate the body with wisdom: bones, flesh, skin, limbs, hair, the six senses, the four great elements, the five constituents, and the hundred spirits. Examine and reflect carefully—there is no true substance. All are temporary aggregates, coalescing to form what seems real. Search within and without—where is the self to be found? Since the body is illusory, the mind becomes empty. Empty and illusory are not real; all are deluded thoughts. Once the delusion of the body is extinguished, all dharmas are likewise. Self and other, right and wrong, love and hate, grasping and rejecting, desire for form, scent, and taste, jealousy, stinginess, greed, killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, deceitful speech, harsh words, divisive speech—all such karmic actions are extinguished in an instant. Within and without are purified and void, and you will naturally meet the true Dao.

Universal Salvation said: Though the body is fleeting and illusory, it is a clod with form. Pain, itching, soreness, and ache, wind, cold, heat, and dampness—internal and external movements and contacts assail it in every thought. The slightest disharmony brings worry and affliction. How, through contemplation, may these be swiftly extinguished?

The Lord of the Dao said: All is delusion; I do not deceive you. All that has form is entirely fleeting and illusory. Because it is fleeting and illusory, it is impermanent in every thought. Sentient beings cling and perceive it as real. If you know the body is not real, all suffering vanishes. Simply forget the self, and all afflictions are extinguished. How then could there be pain, itching, soreness, or ache?

Universal Salvation said: The deluded thoughts of sentient beings are deeply entrenched. To suddenly forget the self is truly impossible. By what expedient means may they be gradually shown the causes and conditions?

The Lord of the Dao said: I previously stated that you must stabilize your resolve and contemplate the body with wisdom, carefully examining and reflecting that there is no true substance. This is how I gradually instruct sentient beings to remove deluded thoughts and clinging. The reason sentient beings cannot yet remove them is that the six senses and three karmas are not purified.

Universal Salvation said: How may the six senses and three karmas be purified?

The Lord of the Dao said: The six senses are: first, the eye sense; second, the ear sense; third, the nose sense; fourth, the tongue sense; fifth, the body sense; sixth, the mind sense. They are called the six senses because they generate all karmic actions. Like grasses and trees producing flowers and leaves, seeds and fruits generating one another, they give rise to the six emotions, six desires, six defilements, six entrances, six thieves, six dusts, and six consciousnesses.

Form, sound, scent, taste, touch, and dharmas are fundamentally empty and quiescent, unmoving to body and mind. Sentient beings cling and deludedly grasp and reject, racing in every thought, fettered by affliction. Due to these causes and conditions, they drift in the cycle of birth and death. If you can employ wisdom and resolve, carefully reflect, and awaken to these six senses, then all senses will be exhausted.

The three karmas are: first, bodily karma; second, mental karma; third, verbal karma. Bodily karma includes killing, stealing, and sexual misconduct. Mental karma includes greed, hatred, and delusion. Verbal karma includes deceitful speech, false speech, harsh speech, and divisive speech—together forming the ten evils. Carefully reflect on these ten: not one is real; all are fleeting and illusory, hence deluded thoughts. Simply gradually extinguish the three karmas and the six senses, diminishing them again and again. Stabilize your resolve and contemplate the body. If you can practice this for a long time, you will naturally meet the true Dao.

**Chapter Twenty-Six: On the Teachings**

The Dao Lord said:
In the beginning, the Primordial One transformed *qi* into three *qi*, dividing them into the Three Heavens.

The first is the Primordial *Qi*, forming the Qingwei Heaven, known as the Jade Pure Realm. This is the transformation of the Heavenly Treasure Lord, from which emerged the Twelve Divisions of the *Dongzhen* Scriptures, teaching the Nine Saints of Heaven.

The second is the Original *Qi*, forming the Yuyu Heaven, known as the Supreme Pure Realm. This is the transformation of the Numinous Treasure Lord, from which emerged the Twelve Divisions of the *Dongxuan* Scriptures, teaching the Nine Perfected of Heaven.

The third is the Mysterious *Qi*, forming the Great Red Heaven, known as the Grand Pure Realm. This is the transformation of the Divine Treasure Lord, from which emerged the Twelve Divisions of the *Dongshen* Scriptures, teaching the Nine Immortals of Heaven.

These thirty-six divisions are also called the Three Vehicles: the Great Vehicle, the Middle Vehicle, and the Lesser Vehicle. They coalesce from the soaring mysterious *qi*, naturally forming chapters—jade characters in golden script, dragon patterns and phoenix seals—each spanning a square *zhang* with eight radiant corners, their luminous teachings circulating throughout the heavens.

From the world’s beginning to its end, through five kalpas, the Dharma Wheel turns ceaselessly, sometimes real, sometimes expedient, now vast, now concise, adapting to capacities to awaken understanding and guide practice in each age. Though heaven and earth may end their course, the Three Caverns remain indestructible, liberating all beings, guiding gods and humans. The Three Realms and the Ten Directions all receive its benefits.

Pujì asked: When did the Three Caverns descend into the world? Did they arrive together, or in succession?

The Dao Lord said:
At the dawn of each kalpa, the *Dongzhen* teachings descend first. People embrace the Dao and hold to virtue, dwelling together in emptiness and non-being, all upholding the true and real, attaining long life without death.

Next, the *Dongxuan* teachings descend. Humanity gradually drifts apart, simplicity scatters, and purity thins; the Dao is lost, and virtue betrayed.

Then the *Dongshen* teachings descend. People grow ever more frivolous, forsaking the true and real, their lifespans shortening.

After this, the human heart decays, the Three Caverns cease to spread, wisdom does not flourish, humans and ghosts intermingle, and the kalpa’s span hastens, falling short of a hundred years. Impermanence prevails in every thought, and death follows without end.

I then reappear in the world, proclaiming the Three Caverns, disseminating their teachings among humanity, adapting to the capacities of each age. I expound the scriptures—sometimes grand, sometimes modest—according to what suits the beings.

Thus, the original texts of the Primordial Beginning were not fully transmitted below. In the Three Pure Realms above and the Four Brahmā Heavens, the true saints cultivate practice, and their texts are complete. Though mountains, rivers, grottoes, and palaces, as well as the immortal abodes of seas and peaks, may have their own practices, these are not fully comprehensive.

Therefore, I commanded Laozi to incarnate in the human realm, to save and deliver all beings, expounding precepts and regulations. Whether among the Yi or the Xia, whether sage or commoner, throughout the Ten Directions, all are enabled to attain liberation.

The great Dharma of the Three Caverns has spread among humanity, exhorting men and women to diligently cultivate and practice. Those who have amassed great sins, burdened by karmic obstructions and sunk in delusion, having no affinity with the Dao, cannot believe or uphold it. They turn instead to false teachings, worshipping various demonic spirits, exhausting their lives in vain, and ultimately descending into hell.

If one can believe in and practice the great Dharma of the Three Caverns, they will enter the Hall of Blessings. Some ascend in broad daylight, some attain liberation through *shijie*, concealing their traces and dwelling in grotto palaces, roaming the world, changing their names to attain long life, enduring through endless kalpas. They refine *qi* and transform their forms, turning spirit to merge with the Dao, unrecognized by others, boundless and infinite.

After my departure, demonic teachings will flourish, and the world will uniformly follow them. People will die young, and warfare, floods, fires, illnesses, and deaths will follow one after another. Nations will fall, families will perish, and these calamities will occur morning and night. Granaries will be emptied to serve demonic and false cults, deceit and corruption will multiply daily, and the age will be swept by frivolity and distortion. Hunger, cold, and suffering will afflict all; fathers and sons will be scattered and displaced. The world will sink into utter ignorance, never to awaken.

I pity you, who have been submerged for kalpas on end, and so I speak these essential words to open the eyes and ears of the blind and deaf.

The scriptures and teachings of the Three Caverns comprise two types: the true Dharma and the adapted Dharma.

The true Dharma is free from all falsity and endures forever.

The adapted Dharma, transmitted through written words, changes and perishes with the times. Within the adapted Dharma, there are five varieties:

First, the coalescence of soaring mysterious *qi*, forming cloud-seals into chapters, their combinations natural and transformations unfathomable. These reside in the Three Pure Realms above, eternally enshrined in the scriptures, enduring for countless kalpas under the protection of true saints.

Second, cloud-script spanning a *zhang*, its eight corners radiant, circulating through the Three Realms and Ten Directions among the five billion heavens, ascending and descending with the kalpas, responding to conditions and spreading transmission.

Third, inscribed and recited in the halls, pavilions, terraces, and chambers of the heavenly palaces, as well as on their gates and doors, to subdue beings and guide their entry into cultivation.

Fourth, floral scripts on jade tablets, bound in precious volumes, found in the square *zhang* of Penglai, the paradises of Lang, and the gardens of Xuanpu. They appear and vanish with the kalpas, teaching gods, immortals, and various demonic spirits.

Fifth, written on paper, silk, bamboo, and wood with ink and lacquer, scattered among humanity, transmitted and recited. They descend at the kalpa’s beginning and ascend at its end, protecting nations, pacifying people, and liberating all beings.

The scriptures are the words of the Primordial Beginning, teaching and transforming beings, enabling them to recognize the root and origin, past-life causes and conditions, the retribution of sin and blessing, the auspices of good and evil, the gates of life and death, and the expedient means of practice. Now, turning from evil to embrace goodness, one preserves and secures life, attains long life and non-action, and returns to the Dao, becoming a model for endless kalpas. Those who uphold them receive blessings; those who cultivate them become immortals.

I have inherited the teachings of the Primordial Beginning to enlighten gods and humans, solely to rescue beings from suffering. You should uphold them.

The Dao Lord addressed Pujì, saying:
From the creation of heaven and earth to the era of the Supreme Sovereign, I have passed through countless kalpas, beyond measure. The teachings I have manifested and the incarnations I have assumed are likewise innumerable.

In the heavens above and the world below, boundless and infinite, I revolve and transform, adapting to conditions to liberate beings. Sometimes I am called the Primordial Beginning, sometimes the Empty Sovereign, sometimes the Most High Heavenly Worthy, sometimes the Boundless, sometimes the Spontaneous, sometimes the Non-Action, sometimes the Great Dao, sometimes the Formless, sometimes the Lofty, sometimes the Nameless, sometimes the Utmost Real, sometimes the Jade Emperor, sometimes the Golden Sovereign, sometimes the Dao Lord, sometimes the Heavenly Elder, sometimes Lord Lao, sometimes the Ancient One, sometimes the Master, sometimes the Great Thousand, sometimes the Dharma King...

When heaven and earth first arose, at the beginning of the Dragon Han kalpa, I was called the Formless, transforming in the Jade Clarity Realm, revealing the *Great Cavern Perfected Scripture*, descending to teach and transform as the Mystic Master of Myriad Heavens, the Supreme Dharma King. After ninety-nine billion, nine hundred ninety-nine million years, in the Yan Kang era, I was called the Nameless, transforming in the Highest Clarity Realm, revealing the *Cavern of Mystery Precious Scripture*; descending to teach and transform as the Medical King of the Three Realms, the Most High Perfected Sovereign.

After eighty-eight billion, eight hundred eighty-eight million years, in the Chi Ming Kai Yun era, I was called the Brahma Form, also named Avalokiteśvara, transforming in the Grand Clarity Realm, revealing the *Cavern of Spirits Immortal Scripture*; descending to teach and transform as the Guide of the Ten Directions, the Utmost Heavenly Worthy. After seventy-seven billion, seven hundred seventy-seven million years, when the Kai Huang era changed its name, I was called the Empty Sovereign, transforming in the Primordial Yang Palace, unfolding the Three Caverns; descending to the human realm as the Most High Dao Lord.

After sixty-six billion, six hundred sixty-six million years, reaching the Shang Huang era, I was called the Primordial Beginning, transforming in the Purple Tenuity Palace, broadly disseminating scriptures and precepts, causing innumerable hosts of Immortal Perfected Ones, Wondrously Practicing Perfected Ones, and Flying Heavenly Spirit Kings to each transform in the human realm, liberating all beings. Such is my revolving transformation—it is likewise inexhaustible.

From kalpa to kalpa, from heaven to heaven, I manifest true responsive transformation bodies according to the times, establishing names in accord with the world, altering forms and titles in myriad differences—yet all are my single body. Sometimes I provisionally assume the roles of master and disciple to awaken one another; sometimes I employ expedient means of priority and sequence to instruct gods and humans.

Now, I entrust this scripture to you for dissemination, that above and below in the heavens, throughout the ten directions and three realms, all men and women may universally witness the Dharma’s resonance.

Pujì proclaimed: Today, I receive the Celestial Worthy’s decree to liberate gods and humans. May I borrow divine power to proclaim this to all heavens, that all may universally hear and know.

The Most High flicked a finger, addressing the assembly of Perfected Ones: Above and below in the heavens, throughout the three realms and ten directions, all divine spirits, Immortal Perfected Ones, and hosts of Sages—this scripture I now entrust to Pujì. Each of you should widely propagate it.

Thereupon, the sacred multitudes of the heavens adorned their jeweled thrones, raised banners and held canopies, burned incense and scattered blossoms. Phoenix carriages and simurgh canopies, thousands of chariots and myriad riders drifted through empty space, bowing in unison, thrice voicing their approval. They reverently received this scripture and returned each to their own abode.

Everywhere, they arrayed hundreds of thousands of myriads of seven-jeweled thrones, expounding day and night, chanting the numinous resonance. They burned myriad measures of sacred incense, scattered a hundred kinds of precious blossoms, performed the music of the ten thousand heavens, and lit lamps of ten thousand luminous spirits. They offered Dharma implements, exquisite foods, and rare delicacies—each in hundreds of thousands of myriads—encircling them on all sides in measureless abundance.

Then, with yellow jade as tablets and purple gold as script, they enshrined it within grotto-palace dragon halls, cloud chambers, and phoenix caskets, inscribing it as *The Most High Numinous Treasure Scripture of Karmic Retribution and Causal Conditions*. Thus concludes Scroll Ten of *The Most High Numinous Treasure Scripture of Karmic Retribution and Causal Conditions*.

chunks.original_text: 太上洞玄灵宝业报因缘经 经名：太上洞玄灵宝业报因缘经。 简称《业报经》。 撰人不详，约出於南北朝末或隋唐之际。 十卷。 底本出处：《正统道藏》洞玄部本文类。 另有敦煌抄本二十余件。 太上洞玄灵宝业报因缘经 目　录 卷一 开度品第一 卷二 善对品第二 恶报品第三 受罪品第四 卷三 忏悔品第五 卷四 奉戒品第六 持斋品第七 卷五 诵念品第八 行道品第九 弘誓品第十 发愿品第十一 赞叹品第十二 布施品第十三 卷六 慈济品第十四 救苦品第十五 卷七 功德品第十六 应感品第十七 福报品第十八 卷八 生神品第十九 卷九 弘救品第二十 证实品第二十一 摄因品第二十二 生化品第二十三 卷十 广统品第二十四 会真品第二十五 叙教品第二十六 流通品第二十七 太上洞玄灵宝业报因缘经卷之一 开度品第一 大慈大悲普济真人，以业报因缘诸问太上。 尔时太上道君在福德天中香积世界，坐光明七宝台上，大会说法。 时普济真人上白天尊曰：普济侍坐无量劫来，未尝见慈尊欢喜得如今日，施大法云，注大法雨，普令见在各得解悟，随分利益不可思议。 愿藉神通，欲观无极世界善恶因缘，开示当来，令知宿命、过去未来三世之事。 说是语已，礼拜伏地，仰听慈颜。 天尊语普济曰：汝今能发如是愿，起大善心，利益一切不可思议。 感此因缘，即施九色光明，彻照诸天百亿世界、乃至下方无量国土，威神变见，洞彻无阂，皎在目前犹如指掌。 普济及诸大众乘此威光，得见诸天诸地善恶因缘，内外备尽，诸天之上，众圣游戏。 次见诸天之下，乃至诸地受苦众生，一一分别以示将来。 诸天之上，见有大圣高真，项负圆明，身相具足，变见自在，大小随宜：或驾景腾空，乘龙驭鹤； 或飞云步虚，鸾舆凤盖。 无量无边见有飞仙天仙、神仙灵人，逍遥无为，光明备身，神通无阂。 见有天男天女、玉童玉女，无鞅数众。 见有凤凰孔雀、狮子辟邪，侍卫左右。 见有金堂玉殿，宝台珠阙。 见有天乐天华、天果天树，万种杂类，不可得名。 见有毒龙猛兽，匝绕城阙。 见有宝池金苑，仙人游戏。 见有天厨天供，百味罗列。 见有诸仙，咨问法相。 见有众圣，广说一乘。 见有天王，以问凶吉。 见有百座千座、乃至万亿宝座，讲说大乘。 见有飞仙、神仙、天仙，诸始学真，问法论难。 见有旛华幢盖，百宝装严。 见有土地，皆是七宝金银珠玉。 见有园苑、竹林、果木、鸟兽、水池，皆悉自然。 见有宫殿、音声、衣服、茵席、毡褥，并非人造。 见有诸仙行道念诵，礼拜赞唱，昼夜不绝。 见有飞台行馆，空裹转移。 见有天衣云盖，虚内相迎。 见有殿堂楼阁，忽然化出。 见有饮食滋味，芬芳流溢。 诸天之上，见有如此福德，快乐自在之处。 复见有如此殿堂、华果，种种供养不可名目。 诸天之下，复见有诸天大圣乘云驾虚，持旛建节，按行众生罪目籍录。 见有诸天仙圣分身变化，或贵或贱，或贫或富，或病或壮，或男或女，或老或少，或大或小，或长或短，种种托形下在人间，教化一切。 见有诸天仙人灵人，及诸飞天神王、善恶童子，日日游行人间，条录善恶以奏诸天。 见有云宫星府、日月宫殿、山川岳渎灵官，考较人民善恶功过。 见有国王舍身布施，以求真道。 见有国王卑身下物，供养三宝。
chunks.translated_text:
**The Supreme Cavern Mystery Numinous Treasure Sutra of Karmic Retribution and Causation**

**Sutra Title:** *The Supreme Cavern Mystery Numinous Treasure Sutra of Karmic Retribution and Causation* (abbreviated as *Sutra of Karmic Retribution*).

Author unknown, likely composed between the late Northern and Southern Dynasties or the Sui-Tang period. Ten fascicles. Base text from *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, Cavern Mystery Division, Textual Category. Over twenty Dunhuang manuscript copies also exist.

---

### **Table of Contents**
**Fascicle One**
1. The Chapter on Universal Salvation

**Fascicle Two**
2. The Chapter on Responding with Goodness
3. The Chapter on Evil Retribution
4. The Chapter on Enduring Punishment

**Fascicle Three**
5. The Chapter on Repentance

**Fascicle Four**
6. The Chapter on Upholding the Precepts
7. The Chapter on Observing Fasts

**Fascicle Five**
8. The Chapter on Recitation and Mindfulness
9. The Chapter on Practicing the Dao
10. The Chapter on Vast Vows
11. The Chapter on Aspiration
12. The Chapter on Praise and Admiration
13. The Chapter on Almsgiving

**Fascicle Six**
14. The Chapter on Compassionate Relief
15. The Chapter on Deliverance from Suffering

**Fascicle Seven**
16. The Chapter on Meritorious Virtue
17. The Chapter on Responsive Manifestations
18. The Chapter on Blessed Retribution

**Fascicle Eight**
19. The Chapter on Generating the Divine

**Fascicle Nine**
20. The Chapter on Vast Salvation
21. The Chapter on Verification and Realization
22. The Chapter on Gathering Causes
23. The Chapter on Birth and Transformation

**Fascicle Ten**
24. The Chapter on Broad Unification
25. The Chapter on Assembly with the Perfected
26. The Chapter on Expounding the Teachings
27. The Chapter on Circulating the Teachings

---

### **The Supreme Cavern Mystery Numinous Treasure Sutra of Karmic Retribution and Causation**
**Fascicle One**
**The Chapter on Universal Salvation (First)**

The Great Compassionate and Universally Salvific Perfected One, regarding the causes and conditions of karmic retribution, inquired of the Supreme.

At that time, the Supreme Lord of the Dao was in the Heaven of Blessed Virtue, within the Fragrant Accumulation World, seated upon a luminous seven-jeweled dais, expounding the Great Teaching to a vast assembly.

Then the Universally Salvific Perfected One approached and addressed the Heavenly Worthy: "For immeasurable kalpas, I have attended upon the Most Compassionate One, yet never have I seen the Merciful Venerable One so joyful as today, bestowing the Great Dharma like clouds, pouring the Great Dharma like rain, enabling all present to attain understanding and awakening, each receiving inconceivable benefits according to their capacity.

I humbly beseech your divine power to reveal the boundless worlds’ causes and conditions of good and evil, illuminating the future so that all may know the affairs of past lives, the three temporal realms—past, present, and future."

Having spoken thus, he prostrated himself upon the ground, gazing upward to behold the Merciful Countenance.

The Heavenly Worthy addressed the Universally Salvific One: "You have now aroused such a vow, generating a mind of great goodness to benefit all beings in ways beyond conception.

In response to this cause and condition, the Heavenly Worthy emitted a nine-colored radiance, penetrating through the heavens of a hundred million worlds, even to the boundless lands below. Through divine transformation, all was revealed without obstruction, as clear as if held in the palm of the hand.

The Universally Salvific One and the great assembly, borne by this majestic light, beheld the causes and conditions of good and evil across all heavens and earths, both inner and outer realms fully displayed. Above the heavens, they saw the host of sages at play.

Next, they saw below the heavens, down to the various earths, the suffering beings enduring punishment, each distinction made manifest for the future.

Above the heavens, they beheld Great Sages and Lofty Perfected Ones, their necks bearing luminous orbs, their bodily marks complete, transforming at will, assuming forms great or small as they pleased: some riding upon light through the void, some mounting dragons or cranes; some soaring on clouds or treading the empty sky, borne by simurgh-drawn chariots or phoenix-canopied carriages. Countless Flying Immortals, Heavenly Immortals, Divine Immortals, and Numinous Beings roamed freely, their bodies suffused with light, their divine powers unobstructed.

They saw heavenly men and heavenly women, jade lads and jade maidens, their numbers beyond reckoning. They saw phoenixes and peacocks, lions and apotropaic beasts, standing guard to left and right. They saw golden halls and jade palaces, jeweled terraces and pearl towers. They saw heavenly music, heavenly flowers, heavenly fruits, and heavenly trees—ten thousand kinds of wonders, beyond naming.

They saw venomous dragons and fierce beasts encircling the city walls. They saw jeweled pools and golden gardens where immortals disported. They saw heavenly kitchens and heavenly offerings, a hundred flavors arrayed. They saw immortals inquiring into the marks of the Dharma. They saw hosts of sages broadly expounding the One Vehicle. They saw heavenly kings seeking divination of fortune and misfortune.

They saw a hundred, a thousand, even ten thousand million jeweled seats where the Great Vehicle was taught. They saw Flying Immortals, Divine Immortals, Heavenly Immortals, and all novice adepts questioning the Dharma and debating its subtleties. They saw banners, flowers, pennants, and canopies adorned with a hundred treasures. They saw lands entirely composed of the seven treasures—gold, silver, pearls, and jade.

They saw gardens, bamboo groves, fruit trees, birds, beasts, and ponds, all naturally arising. They saw palaces, sounds, garments, cushions, and rugs—none crafted by human hands. They saw immortals practicing the Dao, reciting scriptures, bowing in worship, and chanting praises day and night without cease.

They saw flying terraces and traveling pavilions moving through the void. They saw heavenly robes and cloud canopies welcoming one another in the empty sky. They saw halls and towers suddenly manifesting. They saw food and drink, fragrant and overflowing.

Above the heavens, they beheld such realms of blessed virtue, places of joy and freedom. Again, they saw such palaces and flowers, fruits, and myriad offerings beyond description.

Below the heavens, they saw the Great Sages of the heavens riding clouds and traversing the void, bearing banners and holding regalia as they inspected the registers of sentient beings’ transgressions. They saw the Divine Immortals and Sages of the heavens manifesting in various forms—noble or base, poor or rich, sick or robust, male or female, old or young, large or small, tall or short—assuming all manner of guises to descend into the human realm and teach and transform all beings.

They saw the Divine Immortals, Numinous Beings, Flying Heavenly Deities, and the Divine Kings of Good and Evil, who daily roamed the human world, recording good and evil deeds to report to the heavens. They saw the cloud palaces, stellar bureaus, palaces of the sun and moon, and the divine officials of mountains, rivers, peaks, and streams, who examined and weighed the merits and transgressions of the people.

They saw kings who relinquished their bodies and practiced almsgiving to seek the True Dao. They saw kings who humbled themselves and lowered their status to make offerings to the Three Treasures."
