They saw kings who observed fasts and practiced the Dao, recited scriptures and performed repentance rites to deliver themselves. They saw kings who burned incense in the main hall, invited great Dharma masters, and practiced almsgiving and upheld the precepts.

They saw kings who arrayed a hundred jeweled thrones to expound the Great Vehicle, discoursing day and night without cease, elucidating wondrous meanings. They saw kings who personally led their ministers to the temples, offering gold, silver, pearls, and jade; brocades and silks; grains and treasures; carriages and horses; ornaments and adornments; gardens, ponds, and orchards; clothing and utensils—all manner of offerings to cultivate the field of merit.

They saw kings who widely ordained men and women to leave the household life. They saw kings who broadly converted the people of their realm to uphold and propagate the True Dharma. They saw kings who erected grand temples, adorning them in manifold ways. They saw kings who extensively created Dharma bodies, sparing no wealth. They saw kings who copied and transcribed various scriptures, reciting and making offerings to them.

They saw kings who offered banners, flowers, canopies, and parasols; fragrant oils and fine robes—all used in almsgiving to the monastic community. They saw kings who lectured throughout the day, praising and extolling the profound transformation of the Dao. They saw kings who upheld the Great Precepts, never transgressing them. They saw kings who reverently received the Three Caverns’ precious scriptures, wearing them upon their bodies.

They saw kings who constantly cultivated wholesome thoughts, devoting themselves sincerely to the Dao. They saw kings who relinquished their thrones to ministers, themselves leaving the household life. They saw kings who released their palace women, universally allowing them to enter the Dao. They saw kings who distributed their treasures to the poor, aged, and infirm throughout the realm.

They saw kings who humbled themselves, never harming any being. They saw kings whose bearing was dignified and refined, whose wisdom was bright and far-reaching. They saw kings whose lifespans were long. They saw kings who transformed the people through the Dao, bringing joy to all. They saw kings who constantly practiced purity, free from lust and desire.

They saw kings who constantly practiced compassion, refraining from killing or harming. They saw kings who constantly practiced generosity, neither begrudging nor hoarding. They saw kings who constantly maintained joy, free from anger or wrath. They saw kings who constantly practiced frugality, neither extravagant nor indulgent.

They saw kings who constantly practiced great kindness, pitying all beings. They saw kings who constantly practiced diligence, never retreating or turning back. They saw kings who constantly practiced purity, abstaining from wine, meat, pungent foods, and all improper fare. They saw kings who constantly copied scriptures by hand, widely disseminating them.

They saw kings who extensively distributed wealth to support the monastic community. They saw kings who daily discussed and inquired into wondrous principles with Daoist masters. They saw kings who daily held fasts and assemblies, making offerings to Daoist masters. They saw kings who single-mindedly devoted themselves to the Dao, seeking the Dharma of liberation.

They saw kings who sincerely upheld the precepts, seeking the Dharma of transcending the world. They saw kings who performed manifold meritorious deeds to seek immortality. They saw kings who released living beings, sought blessings for the deceased, lit lamps, burned incense, and broadly aided all beings. They saw kings who relinquished their palaces to establish sacred temples.

They saw kings who visited famous mountains to seek the Supreme Dao. They saw kings who invited venerable masters to repent and receive precepts, eradicating past transgressions. They saw empresses who secluded themselves in the inner palace, devoting themselves wholeheartedly to the Dao. They saw empresses who abandoned the six palaces to enter the Dao.

They saw empresses who offered their robes, bedding, and personal treasures in almsgiving. They saw empresses who exhorted and entreated the king to ordain people and propagate the Dharma. They saw empresses who urged the king to invite great masters to lecture on scriptures and engage in doctrinal discussions. They saw empresses who extensively created scriptural images to deliver beings.

They saw empresses who frequently sent fragrant flowers to temples as offerings. They saw empresses who offered a hundred precious items to the monastic community. They saw empresses who upheld the pure precepts, never transgressing them. They saw empresses who remained unstained by the six sense objects, their bodies and minds pure, making offerings to the Three Treasures.

They saw empresses who urged the king to ordain men and women. They saw empresses who constantly cultivated the mind of the Dao, broadly establishing merit. They saw empresses who constantly practiced almsgiving, sparing neither body nor life. They saw empresses who established a hundred seats to lecture on the Great Vehicle.

They saw empresses who wholeheartedly cultivated all virtues. They saw empresses who abandoned the royal palace to enter the mountains and study the Dao. They saw empresses who invited great masters to receive precepts and perform repentance rites. They saw empresses who single-mindedly focused their thoughts, wearing and revering precious scriptures.

They saw empresses who personally prepared a hundred delicacies to offer to the Three Treasures. They saw empresses who diligently created scriptural images, burning incense and performing recitations. They saw empresses who followed the king in generating boundless resolve. They saw princes who, following the king, each generated resolve.

They saw princes who aspired to leave the household life. They saw princes who forsook glory and splendor, donning plain robes to uphold the Dharma. They saw princes who single-mindedly devoted themselves to the Dao, never growing lax. They saw princes who constantly recited true scriptures.

They saw princes who broadly cultivated fields of merit for future karmic conditions. They saw princes who quietly upheld the three karmic actions, keeping their bodies constantly pure. They saw princes who frequently discussed wondrous meanings with Daoist masters. They saw princes who visited Daoist masters to inquire about scriptures and Dharma.

They saw princes who constantly performed prostrations, burned incense, made offerings, and performed repentance rites in sacred temples. They saw ministers who, following the king, generated resolve and broadly established merit. They saw ministers who aspired to leave the household life to uphold and propagate the Great Dharma. They saw ministers whose physical forms were well-proportioned, their karmic rewards fully realized. They saw ministers who erected jeweled thrones, humbly inviting great virtuous masters to expound the Three Caverns of the Mahāyāna, opening the good Way for the land and its people. They saw officials who generated boundless good intentions, following the king in performing various meritorious deeds. They saw officials who constantly maintained singular focus for the benefit of the Great Dharma.

They saw Daoist masters who constantly used scriptures and precepts to admonish the king. They saw Daoist masters who constantly created scriptural images, wishing for the nation’s peace. They saw Daoist masters who taught and transformed the world, constructing sacred temples, halls, pavilions, and towers—each according to their capacity—to serve as future refuges for all beings. They saw Daoist masters who constantly practiced compassion, vowing to deliver all. They saw Daoist masters who frequently arranged hundreds of seats to expound the Mahāyāna, benefiting people and the nation.

They saw Daoist masters who devoted themselves wholeheartedly to the Dao, reciting scriptures and upholding precepts day and night without cease. They saw Daoist masters who broadly established fields of merit by constructing bridges. They saw Daoist masters who diligently attended to beings, constantly expounding wondrous Dharma to guide the deluded. They saw Daoist masters who constantly performed repentance rites and administered precepts for all beings, universally leading them to refuge. They saw Daoist masters who sounded bells and struck chimes in all six periods without rest.

They saw Daoist masters who dwelled alone in empty mountains, absorbing sunlight and consuming pine sap. They saw Daoist masters who widely practiced alms-seeking to relieve the poor and the six afflictions. They saw Daoist masters who used talismans, incantations, decoctions, and medicines to heal all beings of every illness and suffering. They saw Daoist masters of unmatched majesty who served as teachers to gods and humans. They saw Daoist masters who constantly remained in the Daoist sanctuary, copying scriptures and transcribing images.

They saw Daoist masters who secluded themselves in empty chambers, reciting and chanting precious scriptures without pause. They saw Daoist masters whose wisdom and skillful means were unhindered and free. They saw Daoist masters who rejoiced with singular devotion in upholding and propagating the Great Dharma. They saw Daoist masters who constantly generated compassionate minds to deliver all beings. They saw Daoist masters who redeemed lives, relieved hunger and cold, distributed clothing and food, and extensively established fields of merit.

They saw Daoist masters who dug wells by the roadside, built houses and halls, constructed bridges, planted bamboo, trees, flowers, and fruit, and alleviated the toil of others. They saw female officials who constructed dark altars, halls, and expansive courtyards—complete in all directions—to instruct future generations.

They saw female officials who gave alms without stinginess. They saw female officials whose minds were free from envy, transcending self and others. They saw female officials who abstained from grains to purify body and mind. They saw female officials who maintained long fasts and upheld precepts, sincerely devoting themselves to the Dao.

They saw female officials who made various garments to offer to Dharma masters and great virtuous ones. They saw female officials who diligently gazed at the stars and constellations to attain lightness of body. They saw virtuous ones who turned their minds to the Three Treasures without retreat.

They saw virtuous ones who relinquished their bodies, lives, and wealth for almsgiving, making offerings to the Three Treasures. They saw virtuous ones who did not惜 their wives and children, providing for those who had left the household life. They saw virtuous ones who gave their family wealth—fields, dwellings, servants, utensils, carriages, horses, the seven treasures, fine garments, and various precious objects—to make offerings to the Three Treasures.

They saw women who followed their masters and teachers without doubt or hesitation. They saw women who offered their own garments and adornments, using them as the Dharma required. They saw women whose devotion was sincere and unwavering, wholeheartedly serving the Dharma. They saw women who made various Dharma robes to give as alms. They saw women who gathered abundant flowers and fruits to offer to the Three Jewels. They saw women who constantly upheld the sublime precepts with diligence, never retreating. They saw women who purified their six senses, free from desires. They saw women whose minds and conduct were pure and harmonious, unstained by worldly affairs.

They saw halls of fortune where one dwelled in ease, free from striving. They saw Daoist sanctuaries where sutras were constantly expounded. They saw Dharma masters who taught the Great Vehicle, instructing all beings. They saw great virtuous ones who exhorted and guided sentient beings, leading them into the singular good Way. They saw sacred observatories where incense was burned and scriptures recited day and night without weariness. They saw blessed places where joy was constant, untouched by sorrow or grief. They saw good people who ceaselessly cultivated diligence, moment by moment unceasing, upholding the Dao and holding to the sutras.

They saw kings who killed living beings while hunting, harming and oppressing the people. They saw kings who were cruel and tyrannical without measure, leaving the people exhausted and impoverished. They saw kings who indulged in lust and desire, giving free rein to the six senses. They saw kings who destroyed sacred observatories, burning and demolishing Dharma halls. They saw kings who disbelieved in karma, dismissing it as empty fabrication. They saw kings who violated sutras and precepts, showing contempt for monastics. They saw kings who appropriated the property of the Three Jewels for their own use. They saw kings who committed various transgressions in the dark altars and Dharma halls. They saw kings who slaughtered beings within the observatories, leaving them foul and defiled. They saw kings who killed the Dharma bodies of monastics, inflicting cruel punishments. They saw kings who destroyed images of the Dao and burned scriptures. They saw kings who committed countless sins, too many to record. They saw kings who showed contempt for Heaven and Earth, the sun, moon, and stars. They saw kings who slandered themselves, claiming the Dao had no divine power. They saw kings who lacked compassion, engaging in excessive killing and warfare.

They saw empresses who indulged in lust without restraint, poisoning good people. They saw empresses whose hearts did not believe in truth, urging the king to eradicate the sutras and teachings. They saw empresses who scorned sutras and precepts, dismissing them as empty illusions. They saw empresses who committed all manner of evils, so vile that none wished to hear of them. They saw empresses who, out of jealousy, killed the virtuous and upright.

They saw princes who were unrestrained and reckless, destroying the Dao and its scriptures. They saw princes who trampled upon sacred observatories, leaving them extraordinarily defiled. They saw heirs who indulged in depravity and licentiousness, staining the Dharma bodies of monastics. They saw princes who drank wine, ate meat, and slandered the Three Jewels. They saw ministers who lacked faith, urging the king to abolish the Daoist teachings. They saw ministers whose partiality led them to deceive and manipulate the king into harming the Dao and misleading practitioners. They saw ministers who disbelieved in the three periods of past, present, and future karmic causes and conditions, claiming there was no karma.

They saw men and women who slandered the sutras, the great Dao, and the Dharma bodies. They saw men and women who forcibly took sides, distinguishing truth from falsehood. They saw men and women who gave rise to baseless love and hatred, seeing only "this" or "that." They saw men and women who broke fasts and violated precepts. They saw men and women who stole scriptures. They saw men and women who drank wine and ate meat in pure places. They saw men and women who engaged in lustful acts in the domains of the Three Jewels. They saw men and women who defiled sacred observatories with lustful impurities. They saw men and women who engaged in lustful acts with the Dharma bodies of monastics. They saw men and women who slandered the Dharma bodies of monastics. They saw men and women who spoke harshly and sowed discord. They saw men and women who killed their fathers or harmed their mothers, committing the five grave offenses of unfiliality. They saw men and women who were disloyal and unfilial, rebelling against their rulers and fathers. They saw men and women who bullied others, unable to distinguish good from evil. They saw men and women who showed no pity for the poor. They saw men and women who despised the old and sick. They saw men and women who indulged their six senses. They saw men and women who did not cultivate the three karmic actions. They saw men and women who flew hawks and hunted with dogs, killing living beings. They saw men and women who turned their backs on the Dao and betrayed their teachers, breaking vows and oaths.

They saw men and women bound in cangues and fetters, imprisoned, whipped, and tortured. They saw men and women with deafness, blindness, and the six illnesses, their bodies incomplete. They saw men and women impoverished and suffering, unloved by anyone. They saw men and women bedridden with chronic illness, unable to live yet unable to die. They saw men and women afflicted with leprosy, madness, and all manner of perverse diseases. They saw men and women foolish and dull-witted, their bodies incomplete. They saw men and women covered in sores, their bodies oozing pus and blood. They saw men and women harmed by blades, weapons, water, and fire, burned, slashed, and shot. They saw men and women devoured or stung by venomous insects and fierce beasts. They saw men and women orphaned, widowed, hungry, and cold, enduring hardship alone. They saw men and women separated midway through life, never to reunite. They saw men and women torn from their mothers and children, reduced to servitude. They saw men and women whose appearances were so hideous that none wished to look upon them. They saw men and women whose lives were cut short, dying young with unfulfilled longings. They saw men and women enslaved, suffering from hunger, cold, and hardship. They saw men and women born incomplete, with crippled limbs, deafness, blindness, muteness, and a hundred diseases. They saw men and women whose bodies were broken and split, covered in pus and blood, their lips and mouths shattered, noses and eyes crushed, despised by all.

Below the earth, they saw those who trod upon knife mountains, their limbs severed piece by piece.

They saw those whose hands clung to sword trees, their limbs severed joint by joint. They saw those who swallowed fire and ate coals, their bodies exhaling smoke. They saw those crushed by pestles, ground by millstones, reduced to powder. They saw those who embraced bronze pillars, their bodies scorched and charred. They saw those who lay upon iron beds, their fat melting and igniting in flames. They saw those boiled in cauldrons, their flesh dissolved and rotted away. They saw those whose feet were pierced by blades and needles, their hands and feet severed. They saw those whose bodies were sawed apart, blood dripping in streams. They saw those pressed by boulders, blood flowing from their seven orifices. They saw those beaten with iron rods, their bodies streaming with blood. They saw those trapped in freezing ice, their skin splitting open. They saw those engulfed in mountains of fire, their heads and faces scorched. They saw those leaping amidst burning embers, thrashing in agony. They saw those whose bodies were pierced by iron awls, enduring myriad unbearable pains. They saw those mired in filth, shunned by all. They saw those gnawed by bronze hounds, their entrails strewn about. They saw those whose eyes were pecked out by iron birds, their flesh torn apart. They saw those entwined by venomous serpents, devoured and bitten. They saw those seized and torn asunder by ferocious beasts. They saw those whose tongues were pulled out and pierced with iron awls. They saw those whose tongues were plowed by iron plows. They saw those whose bodies were filed to pieces. They saw those hung upside down. They saw those stripped bare. They saw those shackled and bound in chains. They saw those whose bodies were nailed with iron spikes. They saw those whose limbs were severed joint by joint. They saw those whose flesh was carved into pieces. They saw those who drew water from dark waves to irrigate the four rivers. They saw those who carried stones to fill rivers. They saw those reborn as hungry ghosts. They saw those reborn as the six livestock—oxen, sheep, chickens, and dogs. They saw those reborn as barbarians of the frontier. They saw those reborn as slaves and servants. They saw those reborn with the six afflictions—deafness, blindness, muteness, speechlessness, crippled hands, and lame feet. They saw those reborn incomplete. They saw those reborn as venomous serpents. They saw those reborn with the bodies of insects and beasts. They saw those reborn as flies and maggots. They saw those reborn in latrines. They saw those reborn in mire. They saw those reborn with the bodies of all manner of noxious insects, birds, beasts, fish, and turtles.

Now beholding all these conditions across the heavens and the earth, they saw how causes and karmic retribution differed. They wondered: *What cultivation in past lives led to this present existence? What transgressions were committed to incur this fate? What virtues in past lives brought blessings, and what sins in this life brought suffering? Is this the result of natural endowment, karmic retribution, the influence of land and water, or the legacy of one’s parents? Is this the consequence of one’s own actions, the seeds sown in past lives, the sins of one individual, or the misfortunes passed to descendants? Can one be delivered through the cultivation of goodness, or is this fate immutable?*

They entreated the Heavenly Worthy in great compassion to bestow enlightenment, that all beings might awaken to the causes of their past lives.

The Dao Lord replied: *"Excellent, excellent! You have aroused such profound aspiration, opening the gateway to the benefit of all dharmas, awakening sentient beings to the causes of their past lives—this is beyond the reach of thought. Now listen well, and I shall expound these matters for you."*

**The First Scroll of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure Scripture on Karmic Retribution and Refinement ends here.**

**The Second Scroll of the Supreme Cavernous Mystery Numinous Treasure Scripture on Karmic Retribution and Causes**
**Chapter Two: The Discourse on Virtuous Responses**

The Greatly Compassionate and Universally Salvific Perfected One, having inquired about karmic retribution and its causes, addressed the Supreme Dao Lord.

Then, the Supreme Dao Lord spoke to the Universally Salvific One: *"If there are good men and good women who widely create scriptures and images, establish temples to deliver others, practice almsgiving and fasting, rescue the dead and deliver the living, universally save all beings, and make great vows to cultivate vast fields of merit, their roots of goodness unbroken and benefiting all beings, they shall be reborn as kings of heavenly realms. Those who uphold fasts and precepts, recite scriptures and pay homage, meditate upon the true forms of the Dao, burn incense and worship the Three Treasures and the Great Dao, and widely cultivate fields of merit shall be reborn as queens or mothers of nations. Those who make offerings to the Three Treasures, burn incense and light lamps without wearying, and create scriptures and cast images shall be reborn as attendants in the courts of heavenly kings. Those who believe in and delight in the scriptures and dharmas, follow the regulations and practice them, uphold fasts and contemplate the Dao, and give alms to establish merit shall be reborn with wealth, wisdom, and dignified beauty. Those who uphold the scriptures and precepts and maintain recitation and devotion shall be reborn with intelligence and noble distinction. Those who for seven generations have delighted in the Dao and upheld the precepts, recited scriptures, given alms to relieve the poor, delivered the living and the dead, constantly practiced compassion, and made offerings to the Three Treasures without weariness shall be reborn as those who leave the household life. Those who in lifetime after lifetime have accumulated goodness, widely cultivated fields of merit, upheld fasts and precepts, revered the Three Treasures, recited and contemplated the Great Vehicle, refined their conduct, and never violated the precepts shall be reborn as great virtuous Dharma masters. Those who are revered by all, generation after generation, who take refuge in and honor the Three Treasures, deeply cherish the Great Dharma, and cultivate offerings shall be reborn among heavenly beings, their present lives pure, long, and prosperous. Those who make offerings to the Three Treasures and the Dharma bodies of those who have left the household life shall be reborn with long life and dignified beauty. Those who establish monasteries and build numinous altars shall be reborn with great wealth and nobility. Those who revere and believe in the Great Dao of the Heavenly Worthy and meditate with devoted hearts shall be reborn with fully realized Dharma-nature. Those who believe in and uphold the scriptures and precepts without dualistic thoughts, who attain the knowledge of past lives and understand karmic causes, shall be reborn with nobility and beloved by all. Those who revere the Three Treasures, delight in almsgiving, relieve the poor and needy, accomplish merit, and spare nothing shall be reborn in the Central Kingdom with long life, wealth, and nobility. Those who do not kill, steal, or indulge in wine, meat, or excessive food shall be reborn with long life and completeness. Those who delight in reciting scriptures and uphold the Dao with perpetual fasting shall be reborn as those who leave the household life with reverence and faith."*

chunks.original_text: 供养出家师德，敬重三宝一切法身者，得生清浄端正身。 常怜念一切物，慈悲於蠢动者，生高上贵豪身。 今世作帝王、国主者，从累劫修斋奉戒，广种福田，不嗔不恨，多劫多生，设大斋醮济度法界一切有情，命终之后，得生快乐天宫，天衣挂体，食禄自然。 从劫至劫，受天福尽，下降人间，常生帝王人家，作如是福田中来。 若有善男子、善女人广造福田，供养天尊、大道高真，无量劫中作如是种种功德，今世得生皇后、国母身。 若作帝子、王孙、公主、王妃者、从历劫修善、多种因果中来。 长命老寿者，从持斋奉戒、慈悲救度众生中来。 子孙昌炽、长命富贵者，从供养天尊大道中来。 父子、夫妻、男女常同居处者，从柔顺和睦中来。 不相离隔，从恩爱中来。 在处得人敬仰，甘膳美食充身可口者，从培常住福田中来。 豪贵尊重、人见畏敬者，从敬信三宝中来。 富贵丰足者，从布施持斋、成就福田、救济贫穷中来。 聪明智慧越众者，从诵经法能住持中来。 形容端正者，从供养三宝出家法身中来。 若有清浄男女、出家法身，为人敬奉者，从说法教化、持奉斋戒、多种福田中来。 富贵巍巍、永劫不衰者，从布施成就、常住福中来。 所在得人尊敬，贵人爱仰者，从布施、持经、奉戒中来。 身心清浄、智慧聪明者，从护持三洞大乘中来。 所在快乐、无灾厄者，从放生济物，不犯众生身命中来。 身体香洁，众人见爱者，从不饮酒食肉荤辛、常在清浄中来。 子孙丰多，富贵圆满者，从广行布施、修补桥梁、多作福田种种功德中来。 妇人诞生，健贵子胤，夫婿敬爱者，从作道场、教化信心中来。 生世音雅者，从道场中赞咏、三宝敬信中来。 生世欢乐，福庆自然者，从道场中专心至诚闻法听经布施中来。 形容端正，笑语柔和，举止奉圣，得人爱念恭敬美顺者，从供养出家法身、持经护戒中来。 衣食丰足，法服常有人布施，珍玩饰身者，从布施法师大德法服中来。 如是，皆生此世、或宗祖所行所种，致得今身之报。 或一身种善，见世受报。 普济当须明示男女，使识宿命善缘，得福无量。 恶报品第三 尔时，太上道君告普济及在会众真人曰：自今后，若有众生毁坏天尊大道形像者，死入九幽十八地狱，万劫受苦； 苦尽方生，得生人中，受肿癞病，遍身脓血，臭秽腥膻，人不喜见。 訾毁三洞大法经典者，死历九幽，并入酆都； 经千百万劫，方遇圣人救拔得出，生野兽中； 受无量苦，得生人中，舌根烂坏，常有缠喉之疾，眼目有患。 诽谤出家法身者，见世得虫癞病，过去生六畜身。 破坏灵观、玄坛、圣像者，见世眉发堕落，身体不全，拖腰摩胯； 死入寒冰地狱，受苦满足，堕毒蛇身。 不敬天尊、大道、法身者，见世受愚痴、憨矮、癫狂病报，过去生六畜中。 不信经法、宿命报对者，见世盲聋，过去生鸟兽中，经无量劫，方可得脱。 不信罪福因缘者，见世为奴婢，过去生蛮夷中，难遇正法。 轻慢出家法身者，见世跛躄，过去生猪狗中，屎尿之中，常为饮食。 轻慢三宝，获罪如是。 侵常住福地者，见世形容臭膻，过去生粪秽中； 历千万劫，复生污水中，为细线虫。 淫犯出家法身者，见世孤寡，为人憎嫌； 过去生厕溷中，为蛆虫。

Those who make offerings to monastic masters and virtue, and revere the Dharma-body of the Three Treasures in all its forms, shall be reborn with a pure and upright body. Those who constantly pity all beings and show compassion to the lowliest creatures shall be reborn as the highest nobility. Those who are emperors or kings in this life have, over countless kalpas, practiced fasting and upheld the precepts, widely sowed fields of merit, refrained from anger and hatred, and over many kalpas and lives, established grand fasts and jiao rituals to deliver all sentient beings of the Dharma-realm. After the end of their lives, they shall be reborn in the joyous heavenly palaces, their bodies adorned with celestial robes, and partake of natural blessings. From kalpa to kalpa, when their heavenly blessings are exhausted, they shall descend to the human realm and be born into imperial households, thus returning from such fields of merit.

If good men and good women widely cultivate fields of merit, make offerings to the Heavenly Worthy and the lofty perfected of the Great Dao, and perform such manifold acts of merit for immeasurable kalpas, they shall be reborn in this life as empresses or queen mothers. Those who are imperial princes, royal descendants, princesses, or royal consorts arise from the cultivation of goodness and the sowing of karmic causes over many kalpas. Those who enjoy long life and old age arise from upholding fasts and precepts and showing compassion to deliver sentient beings. Those with flourishing descendants and long life in wealth and nobility arise from making offerings to the Heavenly Worthy and the Great Dao. Those whose fathers and sons, husbands and wives, men and women constantly dwell together arise from gentleness, compliance, and harmony. Those who are never separated arise from mutual affection. Those who are revered and provided with sweet and delicious food wherever they go arise from cultivating permanent fields of merit. Those who are noble, honored, and feared by all arise from revering and believing in the Three Treasures. Those who enjoy wealth and abundance arise from almsgiving, fasting, cultivating fields of merit, and relieving the poor. Those who surpass others in wisdom and intelligence arise from reciting scriptures and upholding the Dharma. Those with upright and proper appearances arise from making offerings to the monastic Dharma-bodies of the Three Treasures.

If there are pure men and women or monastic Dharma-bodies who are revered by others, they arise from expounding the Dharma, teaching and transforming, upholding fasts and precepts, and cultivating manifold fields of merit. Those whose nobility and wealth remain unshaken for eternal kalpas arise from the accomplishment of almsgiving and permanent fields of merit. Those who are respected wherever they go and beloved by the noble arise from almsgiving, upholding scriptures, and observing precepts. Those with pure bodies and minds and keen wisdom arise from protecting and upholding the Great Vehicle of the Three Caverns. Those who enjoy happiness and freedom from disasters wherever they go arise from liberating living beings and refraining from harming the lives of sentient beings. Those whose bodies are fragrant and pure, beloved by all, arise from abstaining from wine, meat, and pungent foods, and constantly maintaining purity. Those with numerous descendants and perfect wealth and nobility arise from widely practicing almsgiving, repairing bridges, and performing manifold acts of merit.

Women who give birth to healthy and noble children, cherished by their husbands, arise from conducting Daoist rituals and teaching with faith. Those who are elegant and refined in this life arise from praising and chanting in Daoist rituals and revering the Three Treasures. Those who enjoy happiness and natural blessings in this life arise from single-mindedly and sincerely listening to the Dharma and reciting scriptures in Daoist rituals. Those with upright appearances, gentle speech, reverent conduct, and beloved by all arise from making offerings to monastic Dharma-bodies and upholding scriptures and precepts. Those whose clothing and food are abundant, who constantly receive offerings of monastic robes, and adorn themselves with treasures arise from bestowing monastic robes upon virtuous Dharma-masters.

Thus, all these are the retributions of the deeds sown in this life or by ancestral lineages, resulting in the rewards of the present body. Some sow goodness in one lifetime and receive retribution in this very life. It is essential to universally instruct men and women, enabling them to recognize the good affinities of past lives and attain immeasurable blessings.

**Chapter Three: Retributions of Evil**

Then, the Most High Lord of the Dao addressed Universal Salvation and all the assembled perfected ones, saying: From now on, if any sentient being destroys or defaces the images of the Heavenly Worthy and the Great Dao, they shall, upon death, enter the Nine Dark and Eighteen Hells of the Underworld, suffering for ten thousand kalpas. Only after their suffering is exhausted shall they be reborn among humans, afflicted with swelling and leprosy, their bodies covered in pus and blood, foul and stinking, abhorred by all.

Those who slander the scriptures of the Three Caverns and the Great Dharma shall, upon death, traverse the Nine Dark Hells and enter Fengdu. Only after a thousand or ten thousand kalpas shall they encounter a sage to deliver them, being reborn among wild beasts. After enduring immeasurable suffering, they shall be reborn among humans with rotting tongues, constant throat ailments, and eye diseases. Those who malign monastic Dharma-bodies shall, in this life, contract leprosy and, in past lives, be reborn as livestock. Those who destroy sacred monasteries, altars, or holy images shall, in this life, lose their eyebrows and hair, suffer incomplete bodies, and drag their waists and thighs. Upon death, they shall enter the Hell of Icy Cold, endure suffering to its fullest, and be reborn as venomous snakes.

Those who disrespect the Heavenly Worthy, the Great Dao, or Dharma-bodies shall, in this life, suffer from foolishness, dwarfism, madness, and epilepsy, and in past lives, be reborn among livestock. Those who do not believe in the scriptures, the Dharma, or the retributions of past lives shall, in this life, be blind and deaf, and in past lives, be reborn among birds and beasts. Only after immeasurable kalpas may they escape. Those who do not believe in the karmic causes of sin and merit shall, in this life, be slaves and, in past lives, be reborn among barbarians, rarely encountering the true Dharma. Those who disdain monastic Dharma-bodies shall, in this life, be lame and crippled, and in past lives, be reborn among pigs and dogs, feeding on excrement and urine.

Those who disdain the Three Treasures shall incur such sins. Those who encroach upon permanent fields of merit shall, in this life, have foul and stinking appearances and, in past lives, be reborn in filth. After a thousand or ten thousand kalpas, they shall be reborn in polluted waters as threadworms. Those who commit adultery with monastic Dharma-bodies shall, in this life, be lonely and despised, and in past lives, be reborn in latrines as maggots.

Those who delight in reciting scriptures and uphold the Dao with perpetual fasting shall be reborn as those who leave the household life with reverence and faith."*

chunks.original_text: 邪淫好色者，见世患风邪、癫狂恶病，过去生豭猪中； 经之数劫，生诸般野牛之中。 偷盗三宝财物者，见世贫穷； 过去生奴婢，复生六畜种种禽兽之中，难复人身。 偷盗四辈信施财物者，见世得癫狂病，不闻三宝之名； 过去生愚痴中。 啖食三宝果实、蔬菜者，见世得翻胃，不能进食； 过去生饿虎、毒蛇中，被人打猎，常遭刑宪； 复生人中，更逢渴病。 偷盗斋食及供养宝器、法食者，见世逢霹雳雷电，恶鬼所伤； 过去生蟒蛇身，死堕饿鬼中。 偷盗供养、醮坛器具等物者，见世生下贱，乞索觅食，无饱之身。 毁坏大道形像者，见世生饿狗毒虫身，饥寒无告，永不得食； 过去生猿猴等身。 偷盗经像财物者，见世得癞病，死堕诸地狱，受诸苦恼，万劫千生，不得原赦； 过去生两头毒蛇、恶虫身。 骂詈出家法师身者，见世得风痫重病，过去生野犴身。 凌辱出家法身者，见世遭枷锁、牢狱拷掠，过去生蝇蛆中。 破斋犯戒者，见世得咽喉疾闭之病，过去生虎豹饿狼之中。 借常住三宝财物不还者，十年十倍，死入酆都地狱，鬼拷罪魂，万劫不得原赦； 过去生蛇狮、虮蟟、壁蛛等蛆中。 杀猎众生者，见世得短命，长受风病，常遭牢狱苦厄； 过去生六畜恶兽中。 爱食野兽等肉者，见世值恶病，过去生麋鹿中。 嗜酒好色者，见世风狂，逢猛火烧燎； 过去生淤泥秽土中。 好食荤辛臭秽者，见世得腥膻臭躁身，过去生粪秽中。 持心不坚固、好弄出家人者，见世得猿猴报； 死入镬汤地狱，经无量劫后，生诸鼠趣中； 复生人道，得手脚挛跛之报，皆因不敬三宝中来。 手脚断坏拳缩、一足短者，从不敬三宝中来。 两眼双盲者，从不信经法、轻忽三宝中来。 舌根烂坏者，从訾毁三洞大乘经教中来。 喑痖不能言语者，从道说出家法师中来。 一生以来，多害疮癣，脑疽背瘫，徧身癞疮，皮毛孔窍冲脓血腥膻，癞虫咬啮，昼夜恓惶，求生不得，求死不得者，从诳惑三宝中来。 鼻塞不闻香臭者，从好啖酒肉、五辛荤秽、冲突三宝中来。 身体烂坏，节节自落者，从诽谤三宝中来。 唇攓齿落，鼻梁崩裂者，从毁道场中来。 曲腰歧胸，偻背短脚者，从唝嗃三宝中来。 欺忽三宝，偏眼斜视三宝者，见世受癫狂风邪迷惑病，过去生鳝鱼水蛭中来。 见世愚痴者，从不信因缘罪福中来。 形容疮肿、丑陋者，从骂詈三宝中来。 眼赤口斜，鼻倾不正者，从诽笑出家法身中来。 愚痴长病，意志不足者，从诳惑三宝中来。 劫贼相逢，杀伤财物者，从劫夺三宝财物中来。 水溺漂沉者，从饮酒食腥膻之食，秽慢三宝中来。 火烧灼烂者，从损废三宝中来。 毒蛇吞噬者，从伤杀出家法身中来。 毒蛇恶虫入口鼻者，从恶口咒诅中来。 毒蛇恶虫入孔窍中者，从耽淫中来。 遇虎狼猛兽啖食者，从阴谋恶毒中来。 饥寒冻饿，衣食不充足者，从修斋醮供养三宝、果食道场未散，偷取中来。 偷食上真献御之食者，永堕恶趣，常作饿鬼，海边阿修罗鬼报。 偷盗三宝常住财物与六亲享受者，今世父母离隔，男女常不同居之报。 嫉妬奸淫，破人和合，离人恩爱者，见世受分散之报。 贫穷困苦者，从破斋犯戒中来。 常为奴婢下贱身者，从偷盗悭贪中来。 生世得人憎嫌者，从侨慢唝嗃中来。
chunks.translated_text: Those who indulge in deviant lust and lechery shall, in this life, suffer from wind-induced madness, epilepsy, and malignant diseases, and in past lives, be reborn among boars; after countless kalpas, they shall be reborn among various wild oxen. Those who steal the wealth of the Three Treasures shall, in this life, be impoverished; in past lives, be reborn as slaves and servants, and again among the six domestic animals, various birds and beasts, making it difficult to regain a human form. Those who steal the offerings of the four assemblies shall, in this life, contract epilepsy and madness, never hearing the name of the Three Treasures; in past lives, be reborn in ignorance. Those who consume the fruits and vegetables of the Three Treasures shall, in this life, suffer from regurgitation, unable to eat; in past lives, be reborn among starving tigers and venomous snakes, hunted by men and constantly subjected to punishment; reborn among humans, they shall again suffer from insatiable thirst. Those who steal vegetarian offerings, ritual vessels, and Dharma-food shall, in this life, encounter thunderbolts and lightning, harmed by malevolent spirits; in past lives, be reborn as pythons, and upon death, fall into the realm of hungry ghosts. Those who steal ritual implements and altar vessels shall, in this life, be born into lowly stations, begging for food, never to be sated. Those who destroy images of the Great Dao shall, in this life, be reborn as starving dogs and venomous insects, suffering from hunger and cold, forever denied sustenance; in past lives, be reborn as apes and monkeys. Those who steal the wealth of sutras and images shall, in this life, contract leprosy, and upon death, fall into various hells, enduring all manner of suffering; for ten thousand kalpas and a thousand rebirths, they shall not be pardoned; in past lives, be reborn as two-headed venomous snakes and malignant insects. Those who revile the Dharma-bodies of monastic masters shall, in this life, suffer from severe epilepsy, and in past lives, be reborn as wild yaks. Those who humiliate monastic Dharma-bodies shall, in this life, endure cangues, imprisonment, and torture, and in past lives, be reborn among flies and maggots. Those who break fasts and violate precepts shall, in this life, suffer from throat obstructions, and in past lives, be reborn among tigers, leopards, and starving wolves. Those who borrow the wealth of the Three Treasures and fail to return it shall, after ten years and tenfold repayment, die and enter the Fengdu Hell, where ghosts torture their souls; for ten thousand kalpas, they shall not be pardoned; in past lives, be reborn among snakes, lions, lice, and wall-spiders. Those who hunt and kill sentient beings shall, in this life, be short-lived, constantly afflicted by wind-borne diseases, and frequently endure the sufferings of imprisonment; in past lives, be reborn among the six domestic animals and malignant beasts. Those who relish the flesh of wild beasts shall, in this life, contract malignant diseases, and in past lives, be reborn among deer and elk. Those who indulge in wine and lechery shall, in this life, suffer from madness and be consumed by raging fires; in past lives, be reborn in filthy mud and foul earth. Those who crave pungent, foul, and impure foods shall, in this life, possess bodies reeking of stench and restlessness, and in past lives, be reborn in excrement and filth. Those whose resolve is weak and who toy with monastics shall, in this life, receive the retribution of apes and monkeys; upon death, they shall enter the hell of boiling cauldrons, and after countless kalpas, be reborn among various rodents; reborn among humans, they shall suffer from contracted and crippled limbs, all due to their disrespect of the Three Treasures. Those with crippled, clenched, or shortened limbs come from disrespect of the Three Treasures. Those blind in both eyes come from disbelief in sutras and contempt for the Three Treasures. Those with rotting tongues come from slandering the great Mahayana teachings of the Three Caverns. Those mute and unable to speak come from speaking ill of monastic Dharma-masters. Those who, throughout their lives, suffer from sores, scabs, brain abscesses, back ulcers, leprous sores covering their bodies, with pus and blood oozing from their pores, and leprous insects gnawing at them, tormented day and night, unable to live or die, come from deceiving and deluding the Three Treasures. Those with blocked noses, unable to smell, come from indulging in wine, meat, the five pungent vegetables, and impure foods, and from disrupting the Three Treasures. Those whose bodies rot and fall apart, joint by joint, come from slandering the Three Treasures. Those with cleft lips, fallen teeth, and collapsed nasal bridges come from destroying Daoist sanctuaries. Those with crooked backs, protruding chests, hunched shoulders, and short legs come from mocking the Three Treasures. Those who disdain the Three Treasures and cast sidelong glances at them shall, in this life, suffer from madness, wind-induced delusions, and bewitching diseases, and in past lives, be reborn among eels and leeches. Those who are foolish in this life come from disbelief in the karmic causes of sin and merit. Those with ulcerous, swollen, and ugly appearances come from reviling the Three Treasures. Those with red eyes, twisted mouths, and crooked noses come from ridiculing monastic Dharma-bodies. Those who are foolish, chronically ill, and lacking in will come from deceiving and deluding the Three Treasures. Those who encounter bandits and suffer loss of life and property come from plundering the wealth of the Three Treasures. Those who drown in water come from consuming wine and impure foods, and from disrespecting the Three Treasures. Those who are burned and scorched come from damaging and abandoning the Three Treasures. Those devoured by venomous snakes come from harming and killing monastic Dharma-bodies. Those who have venomous snakes and malignant insects enter their mouths and noses come from cursing with foul language. Those who have venomous snakes and malignant insects enter their orifices come from indulging in lust. Those devoured by tigers, wolves, and fierce beasts come from harboring malicious schemes. Those who suffer from hunger, cold, and starvation, lacking adequate clothing and food, come from stealing from the offerings of the Three Treasures before the fruits and ritual foods have been distributed. Those who steal the food offered to the Highest Perfected shall forever fall into evil destinies, constantly reborn as hungry ghosts, receiving the retribution of asuras by the sea. Those who steal the permanent wealth of the Three Treasures to share with their relatives shall, in this life, be separated from their parents, and their sons and daughters shall not live together. Those who are jealous, commit adultery, and break the harmony of others, separating them from their loved ones, shall, in this life, receive the retribution of separation. Those who are impoverished and distressed come from breaking fasts and violating precepts. Those who are constantly reborn as slaves and lowly beings come from stealing and miserliness. Those who are despised and hated in this life come from arrogance and mockery.

chunks.original_text: 生世耽淫，不避亲疏好丑者，从猪狗六畜中来。 生世嗜酒猖狂者，从鱼鳌虾蟆水族中来。 生世嗜肉好杀者，从毒虫猛兽中来。 生世不净臭秽者，从科斗虫中来。 身体臭秽不浄洁者，从好食五辛猪狗中来。 六畜生身者，从杀生抵债中来。 野兽獐鹿身者，从食肉偷盗中来。 毒蛇蟒蛇身者，从嫉妬毒害中来。 饿虎生身者，从欺凌劫夺中来。 生厕溷中虫者，从淫欲不浄中来。 生虾蟆、科斗身者，从不供养三宝中来。 生鱼鳌水族身者，从轻泄大道经宝中来。 生小虫蚁身者，从违犯经教中来。 猘犬、野猪、豺狼者，从背师弃本中来。 生乳燕、山雀身者，从评论经教、多口合舌中来。 生鸠鸽、老鸦诸鸟身者，从好是作法异常中来。 生鹰、鹯鸱鹞鸟等身者，从破戒违经中来。 生鳏寡孤独、贫寒困苦者，从淫犯出家法身及堕胎害子中来。 形容丑陋者，从诽谤三宝，傲诞出家法身中来。 风邪、癞病、狂言者，从布施不还及堕子落胎中来。 腹大项细者，从灵观玄坛淫欲中来。 牢狱枷锁切身者，从谄毒恶党中来。 鞭棒楚挞者，从毒害众生不慈悲中来。 猫儿、水獭、躁猫等类生身者，从食肉入灵观玄坛中来。 蝜生身者，从食五种荤辛、侵近三宝中来。 豺狼生身者，从贪吝不布施中来。 狐貉生身者，从虚诳娇诈中来。 鼠生身者，从食斋残供、饮酒食肉中来。 蜈蚣、蚰蜓生身者，从阴毒妬害中来。 蜂蟗虺蝎生身者，从咒诅出家法身中来。 蝘蜓、蜥蜴生身者，从欺忽三宝中来。 蜘蛛、蚯蚓生身者，从悭贪盗取中来。 蚊虫、蚤虱生身者，从慢法轻道中来。 边夷下贱、髡头断发、眼深鼻长、身体臭者，从杀生邪淫、不信因缘中来。 如此皆生世所犯罪目，死入地狱，受诸罪讫，更生此身。 亦有见世报而生此身者，悉由先世所犯此身也。 普济，汝当心精信奉，明示将来，令诸男女知其恶业。 故说颂曰： 悭贪不肯布施者，后世贫穷少衣食。 不敬尊师行轻慢，后生下贱奴婢身。 借贷抵债欺负者，后生牛羊猪狗身。 破斋饮酒食肉者，后生饥寒作饿身。 破戒及怀诸嫉妬，后生鸟兽虫蛇身。 毁坏经像及轻慢，后生虫癞脓烂形。 秽污经像及玄坛，后生丑陋不具足。 诽谤三宝并訾毁，后生无告猪羊狗。 偷盗经像诸财物，后生边夷得下贱。 杀害众生无慈念，后生鱼鳌与六畜。 嫉妬胜己杀贤良，后生恶兽毒蛇身。 恶口咒诅无期度，后生猛虎风狂病。 耽淫好色通骨肉，后生豭猪厕溷蛆。 饮酒食肉及五辛，后生腥臭狂邪病。 毁破天尊诸形像，死入九幽主病癞。 訾毁三洞大经法，死入地狱生野兽。 讪谤出家法身者，见世病癞生六畜。 破坏灵观玄像者，眉发堕落身烂坏。 不敬三宝真圣者，见世愚痴作畜生。 不敬经法与宿命，见世盲聋生鸟兽。 不信罪福因缘者，见世奴婢生六夷。 不信出家生轻忽，见世跛□为猪狗。 秽污三宝清浄地，见世腥臭生粪土。 淫犯出家清浄地，见世孤寡生厕溷。 邪淫好色无亲疏，见世风邪生豭猪。 劫夺三宝诸财物，见世贫穷作奴婢。 偷盗常住及侵损，见世风病作牛羊。 费用偷盗信施物，见世癫狂为愚痴。 啖食三宝果核等，见世消渴得瘦病。 偷盗斋食清浄供，见世□生饿鬼。 偷取斋物将己用，见世饥寒不得食。 凌忽骂詈出家人，见世风痫遭牢狱。
chunks.translated_text:
Those born in this world who indulge in lust without regard for kinship or distinction between beauty and ugliness come from the realm of swine, dogs, and the six domestic animals. Those born in this world who are addicted to wine and behave recklessly come from the realm of fish, turtles, frogs, and aquatic creatures. Those born in this world who crave meat and delight in killing come from the realm of venomous insects and fierce beasts. Those born in this world who are filthy and foul come from the realm of tadpoles and worms. Those whose bodies are foul and unclean come from indulging in the five pungent vegetables and the flesh of swine and dogs.

Those reborn as the six domestic animals come from killing living beings to repay debts. Those reborn as wild beasts such as roebucks and deer come from eating meat and stealing. Those reborn as venomous snakes and pythons come from jealousy and malicious harm. Those reborn as starving tigers come from bullying, plundering, and seizing by force. Those born as worms in latrines and cesspits come from lustful and unclean desires. Those reborn as frogs and tadpoles come from failing to make offerings to the Three Treasures. Those reborn as fish, turtles, and aquatic creatures come from carelessly divulging the sacred scriptures and treasures of the Great Dao. Those reborn as small insects and ants come from violating the teachings of the scriptures. Those reborn as mad dogs, wild boars, and jackals come from turning against their masters and abandoning their roots. Those reborn as swallows and mountain sparrows come from criticizing the scriptural teachings and engaging in gossip and slander. Those reborn as turtledoves, crows, and other birds come from delighting in heterodox practices and strange rituals. Those reborn as hawks, kites, sparrowhawks, and other birds of prey come from breaking precepts and violating the scriptures.

Those born as widows, widowers, orphans, and the destitute, suffering from poverty and hardship, come from engaging in lust with those who have left the household life and from aborting or harming children. Those with ugly appearances come from slandering the Three Treasures and arrogantly disparaging those who have left the household life. Those afflicted with wind-induced illnesses, leprosy, and madness come from failing to repay acts of generosity and from aborting or losing children. Those with distended bellies and slender necks come from lustful desires in sacred altars and profound sanctuaries. Those bound by prisons, cangues, and fetters come from flattery and association with malicious factions. Those subjected to whippings and beatings come from harming sentient beings without compassion.

Those reborn as cats, otters, and restless felines come from eating meat in sacred altars and profound sanctuaries. Those reborn as centipedes come from consuming the five pungent vegetables and encroaching upon the Three Treasures. Those reborn as jackals come from miserliness and refusing to make offerings. Those reborn as foxes come from deceit and fraud. Those reborn as rats come from consuming leftover offerings, drinking wine, and eating meat. Those reborn as centipedes and millipedes come from hidden malice and jealousy. Those reborn as wasps, borers, vipers, and scorpions come from cursing those who have left the household life. Those reborn as geckos and lizards come from neglecting and belittling the Three Treasures. Those reborn as spiders and earthworms come from miserliness, greed, and theft. Those reborn as mosquitoes, fleas, and lice come from disdaining the Dharma and belittling the Dao. Those born as barbarians of low status, with shaved heads, deep-set eyes, long noses, and foul bodies, come from killing living beings, engaging in illicit lust, and disbelieving in cause and effect.

All these are the transgressions committed in this life; after death, one falls into hell, endures various punishments, and is then reborn in these forms. Some receive such retribution in this very life and are reborn in these bodies, all due to the transgressions committed in previous lives. Pǔjì, you must wholeheartedly believe and uphold these teachings, clearly instructing future generations so that all men and women may recognize these evil deeds.

Thus, a verse is spoken:

Those who are miserly and unwilling to make offerings
Shall in future lives be poor, lacking clothing and food.
Those who disrespect their teachers and act arrogantly
Shall in future lives be reborn as lowly slaves.
Those who borrow and repay debts through deceit and coercion
Shall in future lives be reborn as oxen, sheep, swine, and dogs.
Those who break fasts, drink wine, and eat meat
Shall in future lives suffer hunger and cold as starving beings.
Those who break precepts and harbor jealousy
Shall in future lives be reborn as birds, beasts, insects, and snakes.
Those who destroy scriptural images and act arrogantly
Shall in future lives be reborn with festering, ulcerous bodies.
Those who defile scriptural images and sacred altars
Shall in future lives be reborn ugly and incomplete.
Those who slander the Three Treasures and speak ill of them
Shall in future lives be reborn as helpless swine, sheep, and dogs.
Those who steal scriptural images and other treasures
Shall in future lives be reborn as barbarians of low status.
Those who kill sentient beings without compassion
Shall in future lives be reborn as fish, turtles, and the six domestic animals.
Those who envy their superiors and kill the virtuous
Shall in future lives be reborn as fierce beasts and venomous snakes.
Those who engage in malicious speech and curses without end
Shall in future lives be reborn as ferocious tigers and suffer from madness.
Those who indulge in lust and debauchery with kin
Shall in future lives be reborn as boars and maggots in latrines.
Those who drink wine, eat meat, and consume the five pungent vegetables
Shall in future lives be reborn with foul odors and suffer from madness.
Those who destroy the images of the Heavenly Worthies
Shall after death fall into the Nine Dark Realms and suffer from leprosy.
Those who disparage the great scriptures of the Three Caverns
Shall after death fall into hell and be reborn as wild beasts.
Those who slander those who have left the household life
Shall in this life suffer from leprosy and be reborn as the six domestic animals.
Those who destroy sacred altars and profound images
Shall lose their eyebrows and hair, and their bodies shall rot.
Those who disrespect the true sages of the Three Treasures
Shall in this life be reborn as foolish beasts.
Those who disrespect the scriptures and past lives
Shall in this life be reborn blind and deaf as birds and beasts.
Those who disbelieve in the causes and effects of sin and merit
Shall in this life be reborn as slaves among the six barbarians.
Those who disbelieve in and belittle those who have left the household life
Shall in this life be reborn lame and as swine and dogs.
Those who defile the pure grounds of the Three Treasures
Shall in this life be reborn foul and stinking in dung and dirt.
Those who engage in lust in the pure grounds of those who have left the household life
Shall in this life be reborn as orphans and in latrines.
Those who engage in illicit lust without regard for kinship
Shall in this life suffer from madness and be reborn as boars.
Those who plunder the treasures of the Three Treasures
Shall in this life be poor and reborn as slaves.
Those who steal and encroach upon the permanent wealth of the Three Treasures
Shall in this life suffer from wind-induced illnesses and be reborn as oxen and sheep.
Those who waste and steal offerings from the faithful
Shall in this life be reborn as madmen and fools.
Those who consume the fruits and seeds offered to the Three Treasures
Shall in this life suffer from wasting diseases and thirst.
Those who steal pure offerings from fasts
Shall in this life be reborn as hungry ghosts.
Those who steal offerings from fasts for personal use
Shall in this life suffer from hunger and cold, unable to obtain food.
Those who belittle and curse those who have left the household life
Shall in this life suffer from wind-induced epilepsy and imprisonment.

chunks.original_text: 破斋犯戒违禁忌，见世噎病生饿鬼。 损害众生无畏惧，见世短命枷锁厄。 食肉腥臭常血秽，见世百病不离身。 嗜酒猖狂无尊卑，见世猛火恶鬼杀。 好食五辛及臭物，见世腥膻生粪土。 绮语戏弄出家人，见世猿猴生鸟兽。 手足挛缩不伸展，不敬三宝得此报。 手足断坏无支节，不敬尊师得此报。 两目俱盲无所见，不信经法得此报。 舌根坏烂及喑痖，诽谤大乘得此报。 言词謇吃不能语，道说出家得此报。 鼻拥不闻香与臭，好食五辛得此报。 身体烂坏脓血流，毁谤三宝得此报。 唇攓齿露鼻梁倒，破坏道场得此报。 举身虫出肉臭烂，算弄三宝得此报。 腰脊曲跌背脚折，欺忽三宝得此报。 瘨狂风邪迷惑病，不信因缘得此报。 形容丑陋并疮尰，咒诅三宝得此报。 眼赤口偏鼻不正，调戏三宝得此报。 愚痴憨矮无意志，诳惑三宝得此报。 劫贼杀害取财物，侵夺三宝得此报。 大水漂溺沉没者，耽色嗜酒得此报。 猛火烧灼形燋烂，损费三宝得此报。 毒蛇吞噬及蜥螫，打骂出家得此报。 毒蛇入口及鼻孔，恶口咒诅得此报。 毒蛇恶虫入窍穴，邪淫放荡得此报。 虎狼猛兽啖食者，阴谋恶毒得此报。 饥冻寒饿常不足，侵损常住得此报。 身常虚乏无气力，不持斋戒得此报。 父母男女常离隔，破人和合得此报。 贫穷困苦常饥寒，破坏斋戒得此报。 为人奴婢常辛苦，偷盗悭贪得此报。 为世憎嫌人不喜，憍慢傲诞得此报。 受身猪狗常啖粪，淫犯六亲得此报。 受身鱼鳌虾蟆身，嗜酒猖狂得此报。 受生毒虫猛兽身，嗜肉杀生得此报。 爱生科斗蝼蚁身，不浄媱秽得此报。 受生獐鹿野兽身，偷盗杀生得此报。 受生蟒蛇毒龙身，嫉妬毒害得此报。 受生饿虎鹰鹞身，欺负抵债得此报。 受生狂犬狐兔身，背师弃本得此报。 受生鸠鸽燕雀身，作法异常得此报。 受生雕鹯鸷鸟身，不用经教得此报。 受生孤寡无男女，堕胎害子得此报。 受生丑陋人憎恶，笑弄出家得此报。 受生癫痫风狂病，布施不还得此报。 受生诸雀鸱鷮身，评论毁教得此报。 受生枷锁常切身，謟毒忠良得此报。 受生棒杖不离身，非法拷楚得此报。 受生猫子狸豹身，食肉入观得此报。 受生蝜臭秽身，荤秽经像得此报。 受身豺狼狐貉身，吝惜虚矫得此报。 受生狂狸鼠身，斋竟食肉得此报。 受生蚰蜓蜕娘身，观中淫欲得此报。 受生蜂虿虺蝎身，咒诅恶口得此报。 受生蝘蜓蜥蜴身，唝嗃傲诞得此报。 受生蜘蛛蚯蚓身，贪淫自盗得此报。 受生蚊虻蚤虱身，轻道慢法得此报。 受罪品第四 太上又语普济曰：地狱受罪因缘，使来主男女识其罪福，归向正真，永断三业，清浄六根。 而为偈曰： 生世不敬信，毁坏道真容，上圣及仙真，灵人与神人，玉童将玉女，金刚并力士，侍卫威神尊，一切诸形像，破损复轻慢，秽污不恭敬，淫犯生戏弄，傲诞自唝嗃。 评论及经法，强说是与非，破斋又破戒，偷盗与贪财。 种种不敬信。 死入九幽狱，备历十八中，足履刀山上，两手攀剑树，裸身抱铜柱，赤体卧铁床，头上戴火山，背常负铁杖。 饥则食火炭，渴则饮铜汁，镬汤沸烂煮，火车烧灼身，碓捣及硙磨，倒悬及倒沥，锯解及刀刑，针锋贯肢节，硖石逼身形，寒冰断筋骨。 煻煨走东西，跳踯不得住，腥秽常臭处，涟汲溟波水，以灌於四渎，恶鸟争啄睛，铜狗来啖啮，毒蛇竞吞噬，牛头折其脊，一日万死生，苦痛不可忍，万劫方得出。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who break fasts, violate precepts, and transgress taboos
Shall in this life suffer from choking diseases and be reborn as hungry ghosts.
Those who harm sentient beings without fear
Shall in this life suffer short lifespans and the misfortune of fetters and shackles.
Those who consume meat, foul and reeking with blood and filth
Shall in this life be afflicted with a hundred diseases that never leave their bodies.
Those who indulge in wine and act wildly without regard for hierarchy
Shall in this life be killed by fierce fires and malevolent ghosts.
Those who relish the five pungent vegetables and foul substances
Shall in this life reek of stench and be born amidst dung and filth.
Those who engage in frivolous speech and mock those who have left the household life
Shall in this life be reborn as monkeys and birds.
Those whose hands and feet are contracted and cannot stretch
Shall receive this retribution for disrespecting the Three Treasures.
Those whose hands and feet are broken and lack joints
Shall receive this retribution for disrespecting their revered teachers.
Those who are completely blind in both eyes
Shall receive this retribution for not believing in the sutras and dharma.
Those whose tongues are rotted and withered, or who are mute
Shall receive this retribution for slandering the Mahayana.
Those who stammer and cannot speak
Shall receive this retribution for disparaging those who have left the household life.
Those whose noses are blocked and cannot smell fragrance or stench
Shall receive this retribution for relishing the five pungent vegetables.
Those whose bodies fester and ooze pus and blood
Shall receive this retribution for slandering the Three Treasures.
Those whose lips curl, teeth protrude, and nasal bridges collapse
Shall receive this retribution for destroying sacred spaces.
Those whose entire bodies teem with worms and reek of rotting flesh
Shall receive this retribution for mocking the Three Treasures.
Those whose waists and spines are bent, backs and legs broken
Shall receive this retribution for deceiving and disregarding the Three Treasures.
Those who suffer from madness, wind-induced illnesses, and delusional diseases
Shall receive this retribution for not believing in causes and conditions.
Those whose appearances are hideous and covered in sores and ulcers
Shall receive this retribution for cursing the Three Treasures.
Those whose eyes are red, mouths askew, and noses crooked
Shall receive this retribution for teasing the Three Treasures.
Those who are foolish, dull, and stunted, lacking will
Shall receive this retribution for deceiving and confusing the Three Treasures.
Those who rob, kill, and seize property
Shall receive this retribution for encroaching upon the Three Treasures.
Those who are swept away and drowned by great floods
Shall receive this retribution for indulging in lust and wine.
Those whose bodies are scorched and charred by fierce fires
Shall receive this retribution for damaging and wasting the Three Treasures.
Those who are devoured by venomous snakes and stung by lizards
Shall receive this retribution for beating and cursing those who have left the household life.
Those who have venomous snakes enter their mouths and nostrils
Shall receive this retribution for uttering malicious curses.
Those who have venomous snakes and vile insects enter their orifices
Shall receive this retribution for lewdness and debauchery.
Those who are devoured by tigers and wolves
Shall receive this retribution for harboring malicious schemes.
Those who constantly suffer from hunger, cold, and starvation
Shall receive this retribution for encroaching upon permanent wealth.
Those whose bodies are perpetually weak and devoid of strength
Shall receive this retribution for not observing fasts and precepts.
Those whose parents, sons, and daughters are constantly separated
Shall receive this retribution for disrupting harmony among others.
Those who are impoverished and destitute, constantly suffering from hunger and cold
Shall receive this retribution for breaking fasts and precepts.
Those who are enslaved and endure constant toil
Shall receive this retribution for stealing and miserly greed.
Those who are despised and disliked by others
Shall receive this retribution for arrogance and insolence.
Those who are reborn as pigs and dogs, constantly eating filth
Shall receive this retribution for committing incest with the six relations.
Those who are reborn as fish, turtles, and frogs
Shall receive this retribution for indulging in wine and acting wildly.
Those who are reborn as venomous insects and fierce beasts
Shall receive this retribution for relishing meat and killing living beings.
Those who are reborn as tadpoles and ants
Shall receive this retribution for unclean and lewd behavior.
Those who are reborn as roebucks and wild beasts
Shall receive this retribution for stealing and killing living beings.
Those who are reborn as pythons and venomous dragons
Shall receive this retribution for jealousy and malice.
Those who are reborn as starving tigers and hawks
Shall receive this retribution for cheating and defaulting on debts.
Those who are reborn as mad dogs, foxes, and hares
Shall receive this retribution for forsaking their teachers and abandoning their roots.
Those who are reborn as turtledoves and sparrows
Shall receive this retribution for practicing aberrant dharma.
Those who are reborn as eagles and hawks
Shall receive this retribution for disregarding the sutras and teachings.
Those who are reborn childless and lonely
Shall receive this retribution for inducing miscarriages and harming children.
Those who are reborn hideous and despised by others
Shall receive this retribution for mocking those who have left the household life.
Those who are reborn with epilepsy and wind-induced madness
Shall receive this retribution for not repaying acts of generosity.
Those who are reborn as various birds and owls
Shall receive this retribution for criticizing and slandering the teachings.
Those who are reborn with fetters and shackles constantly binding their bodies
Shall receive this retribution for flattering the wicked and poisoning the loyal.
Those who are reborn with rods and cudgels never leaving their bodies
Shall receive this retribution for unlawful torture.
Those who are reborn as cats, civets, and leopards
Shall receive this retribution for consuming meat in sacred spaces.
Those who are reborn as stinking and filthy insects
Shall receive this retribution for defiling sutras and images with impure substances.
Those who are reborn as jackals, wolves, foxes, and raccoon dogs
Shall receive this retribution for miserliness and hypocrisy.
Those who are reborn as mad beasts and rats
Shall receive this retribution for consuming meat after completing fasts.
Those who are reborn as centipedes and moths
Shall receive this retribution for indulging in lust within sacred spaces.
Those who are reborn as wasps, scorpions, and vipers
Shall receive this retribution for cursing and uttering malicious speech.
Those who are reborn as geckos and lizards
Shall receive this retribution for arrogance and insolence.
Those who are reborn as spiders and earthworms
Shall receive this retribution for lustful greed and self-theft.
Those who are reborn as mosquitoes, horseflies, fleas, and lice
Shall receive this retribution for belittling the Dao and disdaining the dharma.

**The Fourth Category of Retributions**

The Most High further addressed Puji, saying: The causes and conditions of suffering in hell enable the men and women of this world to recognize their sins and blessings, turn toward the true and upright, forever sever the three karmic actions, and purify the six senses. Thus, he spoke in verse:

In this life, lacking reverence and faith,
Destroying the true forms of the Dao,
The exalted sages and immortals,
The numinous and divine beings,
The jade lads and jade maidens,
The vajra and the mighty warriors,
The guardian deities of majestic might,
All the various forms and images—
Those who damage and disdain them,
Defile and disrespect them,
Commit lewd acts and mock them,
Act arrogantly and insolently,
Criticize and debate the sutras and dharma,
Forcefully assert right and wrong,
Break fasts and violate precepts,
Steal and covet wealth—
All such acts of irreverence and disbelief
Lead to death and entry into the Nine Dark Hells,
Where they endure the eighteen realms of suffering:
Walking barefoot upon mountains of knives,
Clinging with both hands to trees of swords,
Embracing naked the bronze pillars,
Lying unclothed upon iron beds,
Wearing mountains of fire upon their heads,
Constantly bearing iron rods upon their backs.
Hungry, they eat burning coals;
Thirsty, they drink molten bronze.
Boiled in cauldrons of seething broth,
Their bodies scorched by fire chariots,
Pounded by pestles and ground by mills,
Hung upside down and drained of blood,
Sawn apart and subjected to blade punishments,
Their limbs and joints pierced by needle points,
Crushed by boulders pressing upon their bodies,
Their sinews and bones severed by freezing ice.
Scurrying through burning embers,
Leaping and bounding without respite,
Dwelling in perpetually foul and stinking places,
Drawing water from dark and swirling waves
To pour into the four great rivers.
Fierce birds contend to peck out their eyes,
Bronze dogs come to gnaw at their flesh,
Venomous snakes vie to devour them,
Ox-headed demons break their spines.
In a single day, they die and are reborn ten thousand times,
Their suffering unbearable,
Only to emerge after ten thousand kalpas.

chunks.original_text: 前世破斋者，死受饿鬼身，饥则食猛火，后生得噎病，复成脓血形。 前世犯经戒，死入刀针狱，左右穿其身，万痛不可忍； 后生得长病，求生死不得。 前世偷斋食，死入镬汤煮，渍溃骨肉分，日夜无休息； 后生为贫寒，衣食常不足。 前世偷钱财，死入刀山狱，分割於身形，节节自断绝； 后生病癞身，为人不喜见。 前世笑三宝，死受铜灌口，百节皆火燃，形容并燋烂； 后生不具足，六疾缠其身。 前世不敬信，死入剑树狱，手足寸寸断，日夜不暂停，楚痛彻心骨； 后生为愚痴。 前世生轻慢，欺弄於三宝，死入火车狱，形容尽憔烂； 后生为丑陋，所在得人恶。 前世为口舌，诽谤出家人，淫犯及调弄，死入泥犁狱，铁犁耕其舌； 后生厕溷中，或作诸猪狗。 前世毁经教，死被铁杖拷，昼夜不离身，遍体皆流血； 后生无鼻舌，世人常憎嫌。 前生杀众生，牛羊猪鸡狗，鹅鸭雉兔辈，獐鹿虎豹属，鸱鸦及燕雀，豺狼狐貉狖，驼骡驴马类，鱼鳌鼋鼉鳝，螺蚬虾蚌蛤，蚰蜓蜈蚣等，蛣蜣蝼蚁等，蛭蜞蚊蚤虱，蝜蟠蚝蜡虫，熊豹诸兽等，狮猿猴及虎，一切飞走众，种种皆杀伐，不生慈善心，遇者悉残害； 死入诸地狱，备历於众苦，旦夕受痛恼，楚痛难居处； 是诸牛羊辈，悉皆来索命，俱言吃我肉，或道杀我身，此日无方便，今日捉得你，须还我昔债，求走亦无路； 魔王开罪薄，勘会知其实，一一还他命，万劫不得脱； 后生受此身，复作牛猪羊，乃至鹅鸭辈，任他还杀伐，以偿前身罪，犹如种五谷。 前世行偷盗，窃取三宝财，斋戒或信物，父母男女财，天王及百姓，一切非己物，见作生盗心，常行不善行，劫夺於行旅，恐胁或断命，穿墙与抄掠，正昼将夜中，常伺其空阒，牛羊及奴婢，资财与珠玉，绢布玩弄等，毡褥及衣服，器具诸调度，果菜并米麦，丝缕及毫发，抄合将斗升，方便皆窃取； 死入火车狱，形容灼烂苦； 后生为牛马，为人偿宿债，颔穿脊皮断，鼻穴肌肉裂，饥渴常辛苦，口中不能语，任人将杀戮，以报偷盗罪。 前世行邪淫，放荡无期度，奸淫人妻妾，离隔分骨肉，六亲相通同，以及出家人，乃至於六畜； 手扎并他物，着处生邪心，不择於善恶，或於清浄地，灵观玄坛内，对经或近像，裸露天地间，日月星辰下，不避於鬼神，名山大泽侧，社庙神祠中，种种生诸淫，放纵於欲心； 死入九幽狱，男抱火铜柱，女卧热铁床，遍身烟火生，脂肉皆燋烂，百节皆断坏； 更加镬汤煮，铁杖昼夜拷； 复入寒冰狱，擘裂於身心，碓捣硙复磨，锯解碓锉斫； 复生粪秽中，受身厕内蛆，或作猪狗形，展转臭秽间； 纵更受人身，风狂邪病形，愚痴加丑陋，孤寡及贫穷，人所不欲见。 前生苦悭贪，所在求人物，积财如山岳，心常吞江海，常自不厌足； 持斋授戒处，造像及写经，营建於灵观，烧香燃灯所，凡厥作功德，不肯施一毫，就中为方便，常欲觅利益； 死入寒冰狱，冻断其身形，百节皆破坏，后生在边夷，或为人奴婢，或复作牛羊，驼骡驴马身，负重使致远，颔穿及肉断，辛苦不得息，饥渴常在身，身死食人肉； 万劫更受生，还为不具足，手孪或脚跛，眼盲或耳聋，鼻攓口偏斜，胸高腰脊曲，形容复丑陋，所在无人惜。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who broke fasts in past lives are reborn as hungry ghosts, their hunger fed by raging flames; in later lives, they suffer from choking sickness, their bodies festering with pus and blood. Those who violated sutras and precepts descend into the Needle and Blade Hell, their bodies pierced from left to right, enduring unbearable agony; in later lives, they are afflicted with chronic illness, longing for death yet unable to die. Those who stole from fasts or offerings plunge into cauldrons of boiling broth, their flesh and bones dissolving in ceaseless torment; in later lives, they endure poverty, never having enough food or clothing. Those who stole wealth fall into the Blade Mountain Hell, their bodies sliced apart, their limbs severed joint by joint; in later lives, they are stricken with leprosy, shunned by all. Those who mocked the Three Treasures suffer molten bronze poured down their throats, their joints aflame, their forms charred and rotting; in later lives, they are born incomplete, plagued by the six afflictions. Those who lacked reverence and faith enter the Sword Tree Hell, their hands and feet severed inch by inch, their torment unrelenting, pain piercing bone and marrow; in later lives, they are born foolish and dull. Those who acted with arrogance, deceiving and mocking the Three Treasures, descend into the Fire Chariot Hell, their bodies scorched and ravaged; in later lives, they are born hideous, despised wherever they go. Those who used their tongues to slander monastics, committing adultery or deceit, fall into the Hell of Unrelenting Torment, their tongues plowed by iron plows; in later lives, they are reborn in filth, as maggots in latrines or as swine and dogs. Those who destroyed scriptures and teachings are beaten with iron rods day and night, their bodies drenched in blood; in later lives, they are born without noses or tongues, despised by all.

Those who killed living beings—cattle, sheep, pigs, chickens, dogs, geese, ducks, pheasants, rabbits, roe deer, stags, tigers, leopards, owls, crows, swallows, sparrows, jackals, wolves, foxes, raccoon dogs, yaks, mules, donkeys, horses, fish, soft-shelled turtles, alligators, eels, snails, clams, shrimp, mussels, centipedes, millipedes, dung beetles, mole crickets, ants, leeches, water bugs, mosquitoes, fleas, lice, pill bugs, slugs, silkworms, bears, panthers, lions, gibbons, monkeys, and all creatures that fly or walk—without a heart of compassion, slaughtering whatever they encountered, descend into the various hells, enduring every torment, their suffering unending. Each day, they die and are reborn ten thousand times, their pain unbearable. The very creatures they killed—cattle, sheep, and others—come to demand their lives, crying, *"You ate my flesh!"* or *"You killed me!"* With no escape, they are seized, forced to repay their debts. The demon kings consult their ledgers of sins, verifying each transgression, and one by one, they exact repayment, trapping the offenders for ten thousand kalpas. In later lives, they are reborn as cattle, pigs, sheep, or even geese and ducks, slaughtered at will to repay their past sins, like seeds sown to yield their harvest.

Those who committed theft, stealing from the Three Treasures, offerings, or the possessions of parents, children, devas, or common folk—anything not their own—nurturing thieving hearts and persistently wicked deeds, robbing travelers, threatening lives, breaking through walls, plundering by day or night, lurking in shadows, seizing cattle, sheep, servants, wealth, jewels, silks, fabrics, carpets, clothing, utensils, provisions, fruits, vegetables, grains, threads, or even a single hair, measuring their spoils by the sheng or dou, all stolen through cunning—fall into the Fire Chariot Hell, their bodies scorched and tormented. In later lives, they are reborn as oxen or horses, repaying their debts to others, their necks pierced, their backs flayed, their nostrils and flesh torn, enduring hunger and thirst, unable to speak, slaughtered at will to atone for their theft.

Those who indulged in illicit lust, unrestrained and boundless, seducing the wives and concubines of others, tearing families apart, engaging in incest with relatives, even with monastics or livestock, using hands or objects to arouse desire, heedless of good or evil, defiling sacred grounds, temples, altars, places near scriptures or images, exposing themselves beneath heaven and earth, under the sun, moon, and stars, disrespecting gods and spirits, in mountains, marshes, shrines, or temples, giving free rein to their desires—fall into the Nine Dark Hells. Men embrace burning bronze pillars, women lie upon searing iron beds, their bodies engulfed in flames, their flesh and fat charred, their joints shattered. They are boiled in cauldrons, beaten with iron rods day and night, then cast into the Hell of Freezing Ice, their bodies torn apart, pounded, ground, sawn, crushed, and hacked. Later, they are reborn in filth, as maggots in latrines or as swine and dogs, wallowing in foulness. Even if reborn as humans, they suffer madness, deformity, foolishness, ugliness, loneliness, poverty, and are shunned by all.

Those who were miserly and greedy, hoarding wealth like mountains, their hearts swallowing rivers and seas, never satisfied, refusing to give even a hair’s worth at fasts, precept ceremonies, image-making, scripture-copying, temple construction, incense offerings, or lamp-lighting—any meritorious act—always scheming for profit, descend into the Hell of Freezing Ice, their bodies frozen and shattered, their joints broken. In later lives, they are born among barbarians, as slaves or servants, or as cattle, sheep, camels, mules, donkeys, or horses, burdened with heavy loads, their necks pierced, their flesh torn, toiling endlessly, hunger and thirst their constant companions, their bodies devoured by others after death. For ten thousand kalpas, they are reborn incomplete—hands crippled, feet lame, eyes blind, ears deaf, noses flattened, mouths twisted, chests protruding, spines bent, their forms hideous, pitied by none.

chunks.original_text: 生世多瞋怒，常生毒害心，意中常迫连，瞋男或瞋女，畜生及奴婢，似此煎愁身，持刀或持舍，惟欲害於物，愤愤止恚恨曾不少时喜； 死入针锋狱，左右贯其身，连心及肝胆，洞肠达其胁，血出无斛数； 后生为虾蟆，怒目不得语，或为鯸鱼臣鱼，目瞋浮水上，鸱鸢竞来取，分张吃其肉； 纵得生人中，还为愚痴报，作人常丑拙，言词无方便，语则逆人意，无人怜爱者。 前世常愚痴，不信罪福因，笑人作功德，常言无宿命，不敬於日月，天地及星辰，一切诸鬼神，莫不生轻慢，常行不善事，种种皆为恶； 死入十八狱，备历诸苦恼，万劫生蛇身，心中常有毒，腹中无脏腑，饥渴不得食，人皆见欲杀； 纵得生人道，还得愚憨报。 前世为绮语，并及於妄言，娇诳三宝前，父母及男女，君王与百姓，凡是合会处，莫不生离间，谗害於忠良，离异人朋友，嫉妬恶胜己，传言作口舌，浪说为是非，转虚以为实，用白反作黑，道说人长短，强知多是非，所生破乱； 死入拔舌狱，铁锥刺其口，石逼身形，啖食诸臭秽，令舌长百尺，以钉钉其舌，滴滴血流出； 后生为狗身，啖食诸臭秽，昼夜不得眠，常为犬吠守，纵得生人身，喑痖不得语，或复为謇吃。 前世恶口舌，骂詈亲疏人，不择善恶言，随口即复出，畜生与猪狗，虫生将虺蝎，世间诸恶物，无种不比数； 呼天或叫地，引鬼复牵神，上及於三宝，天地日月星； 咒诅相厌祷，书名画形影，捏土或刻木，结彩与图像，爪发衣服具，井灶流水上，门户行道中，神庙星月下，车行狗吠处，社稷山林内，针刺刀断项，反缠鞭其脊，无所法不为； 厌祷於忠良，国君及大臣，公侯或百官，父母与妻子，奴婢将剩妾，不问其贵贱，着处遭毒口，世间共不喜； 死被镕铜灌，百体皆烟出，后生为蜂虿，恶虫与虺蝎，蜈蚣蚰蜓等； 复生於螺蚌，尾上常擎毒，只欲损於物，合口不得语，人行永不近，缩身便入壳； 纵得受人身，亦复为喑吃。 前世多戏笑，调弄於诸人，死被铁鸟啄，眼睛俱迸出，鼻口中流血，痛毒不可忍； 后生为兔身，唇划不能语，人见皆逐，鹰犬亦捉捽； 纵得受人身，还复为喑痖。 前世嗜酒肉，啖食於五辛，出入法堂中，近经又近像，秽污出家人，游行诸浄地，玄坛及灵观； 不避於罪福，醉乱或猖狂，元不畏尊卑，恶口将恶语，骂辱於三宝； 或於天地内，人鬼与神灵，父母并男女，形名人善恶，道说他是非； 死入粪秽狱，臭秽不可与，万劫方得生，受形更复恶，厕溷内作虫，生身俱不浄，或作蛣蜣等、蝇蛆及猪狗，或作蝜蟠虫，臭秽人不喜； 纵得受人身，形容恒丑恶，遍身皆臭秽，腥臊如狐貉，口齿自高下，面目常肿漏，所在得人嫌，男女亦不喜。 前世抵债者，借贷不肯还，因公恃势力，欺忽於世人； 死入倒悬狱，或处倒沥地，动则经万劫； 后生为骡驴，或作病患狗，乃复为牛马，负重常辛苦。 前世违经教，自作一法则，弃本不尊师，诳惑於贤愚； 死入大地狱，遍受於苦毒，刀锋望心刺，铁锥劖其舌，百节钉铁钉； 后生为鹅鸭，或为鱼鳌身，杀戮不能语，任人生与活； 纵复生人身，即为痴聋痖。 前世不信善，侵夺於常住，寸缕及毫毛，果菜与米麦； 死入十八狱，种种受诸苦；
chunks.translated_text:
Those who in life harbor much wrath and anger, their hearts ever poisoned with malice, their minds constantly oppressed—whether raging at men or women, beasts or servants—torment themselves with ceaseless fury. Wielding knives or cudgels, they seek only to harm living things, their resentment unabated, their hatred never yielding even a moment’s joy. At death, they descend into the Hell of Needle Peaks, their bodies pierced from left to right, needles driven through heart and liver, intestines and flanks, blood flowing without measure. In later lives, they are reborn as toads, their eyes bulging yet unable to speak, or as pufferfish and stingrays, glaring upon the water’s surface, only to be seized by hawks and kites, their flesh torn and devoured. Should they be reborn among humans, they still bear the retribution of folly—ugly and clumsy, their words unskillful, their speech ever offending others, met with no pity or affection.

Those who in former lives were ever foolish, disbelieving in the causes of sin and blessing, mocking others’ meritorious deeds, claiming there is no past or future life, showing no reverence for sun and moon, heaven and earth, or the stars, scorning all spirits and gods, persistently committing evil, their deeds wholly wicked—at death, they enter the eighteen hells, enduring every torment. For ten thousand kalpas, they are reborn as serpents, their hearts filled with venom, their bellies devoid of organs, hunger and thirst unrelieved, all who see them seeking to kill. Should they be reborn among humans, they still bear the retribution of dull-wittedness.

Those who in past lives indulged in frivolous speech and falsehoods, deceiving before the Three Treasures, parents, men and women, kings and commoners—wherever gatherings occurred, they sowed discord, slandered the loyal and good, severed friendships, envied and resented those superior to themselves, spreading rumors and strife, turning falsehoods into truths, white into black, speaking ill of others’ faults, pretending knowledge of right and wrong, their lives marked by ruin—at death, they enter the Hell of Tongue-Ripping, their mouths pierced by iron awls, their bodies crushed by stones, forced to consume foul filth, their tongues stretched a hundred feet, nailed in place, blood dripping endlessly. In later lives, they are reborn as dogs, feeding on foulness, sleepless day and night, ever barking in guard, or should they be reborn among humans, mute or stammering.

Those who in former lives wielded vicious tongues, cursing kin and stranger alike, sparing no one with their words, whatever vile speech arose from their mouths—comparing others to beasts, swine, or dogs, to worms, vipers, or scorpions, to all manner of foul creatures—calling upon heaven and earth, invoking ghosts and gods, even the Three Treasures, sun, moon, and stars; uttering curses and malevolent prayers, inscribing names or drawing images, molding clay or carving wood, tying colored threads or painting likenesses, using nails, hair, or clothing, defiling wells, hearths, flowing water, doorways, roads, sacred groves, altars, or places where carriages pass and dogs bark—directing their malice toward the loyal and good, kings and ministers, nobles and officials, parents, wives, and children, servants and concubines, sparing none regardless of rank, their venomous words met with universal disdain—at death, molten copper is poured down their throats, their bodies smoking from every pore. In later lives, they are reborn as wasps, venomous insects, vipers, scorpions, centipedes, or millipedes; or as snails and clams, their tails bearing poison, ever seeking to harm, yet unable to speak, shunned by all, retreating into their shells. Should they be reborn among humans, they remain mute or stammering.

Those who in past lives indulged in mockery and jest, teasing and provoking others—at death, iron birds peck out their eyes, blood streaming from nose and mouth, their agony unbearable. In later lives, they are reborn as hares, their lips cleft and unable to speak, pursued by all, seized by hawks and hounds. Should they be reborn among humans, they remain mute.

Those who in former lives craved wine and meat, consuming the five pungent roots, entering monastic halls, approaching scriptures and images, defiling monastics, wandering through pure lands, sacred precincts, and divine temples; heedless of sin and blessing, drunken and reckless, showing no respect for high or low, spewing vile words and curses at the Three Treasures; or within heaven and earth, among humans, ghosts, and spirits, parents, men and women, spreading slander and discord—at death, they enter the Hell of Filth, its stench unbearable, suffering for ten thousand kalpas before rebirth, their forms ever vile, becoming worms in latrines, their bodies wholly impure, or as dung beetles, flies, maggots, swine, or dogs, or as millipedes, loathed by all. Should they be reborn among humans, their appearance remains hideous, their bodies foul and stinking, rank as foxes, their teeth uneven, their faces swollen and festering, met with disgust wherever they go, shunned by men and women alike.

Those who in past lives defaulted on debts, refusing to repay what they borrowed, abusing power to oppress others—at death, they enter the Hell of Inverted Suspension, or the Hell of Dripping Blood, their suffering enduring for ten thousand kalpas. In later lives, they are reborn as mules or donkeys, or as sickly dogs, or as oxen and horses, burdened with toil and hardship.

Those who in former lives defied the teachings, creating their own doctrines, abandoning their roots and disrespecting their teachers, deceiving both wise and foolish—at death, they enter the Great Hell, enduring every torment, blades piercing their hearts, iron awls rending their tongues, their joints nailed with iron spikes. In later lives, they are reborn as geese or ducks, or as fish and turtles, slaughtered without protest, their lives at the mercy of others. Should they be reborn among humans, they remain dull, deaf, or mute.

Those who in past lives disbelieved in goodness, seizing what belonged to the monastic community—even a thread or a hair, fruits, vegetables, rice, or wheat—at death, they enter the eighteen hells, enduring every suffering.
